<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Argentina</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in South America</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Argentina_(disambiguation)" title="Argentina (disambiguation)">Argentina (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"The Argentine" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Argentine_(disambiguation)" title="Argentine (disambiguation)">Argentine (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"República Argentina" redirects here. For the metro station, see <a href="/wiki/Rep%C3%BAblica_Argentina_(Madrid_Metro)" title="República Argentina (Madrid Metro)">República Argentina (Madrid Metro)</a>.</div>
<p>

</p>

<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-note-lang-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-note-lang_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Though not declared official <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i>, the Spanish language is the only one used in the wording of laws, decrees, resolutions, official documents and public acts thus making it the <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> official language.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-note-ethnicity-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-note-ethnicity_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many White Argentines are descendants of many different European countries, however, the majority of them have at least partial or mixed Spanish or Italian ancestry.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">No recent Argentine census has included comprehensive questions or results on ethnicity. As such, non-government sources give varying estimates. This include the CIA Factbook<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[7]</a></sup> and a survey conducted by <a href="/wiki/Latinobar%C3%B3metro" title="Latinobarómetro">Latinobarómetro</a>, answered by a handful of Argentine citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[8]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-note-train-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-note-train_21-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Since 10 June 1945, but trains are still driven on left.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Argentina</b> (<small>Spanish pronunciation: </small><span class="IPA" lang="es-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[aɾxenˈtina]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es_Argentina.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0d/Es_Argentina.ogg" title="Es Argentina.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Argentine Republic</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-altnames_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-altnames-2">[A]</a></sup> (Spanish: <i lang="es">República Argentina</i>),  is a country in the southern half of <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>. Argentina covers an area of 2,780,400 km<sup>2</sup> (1,073,500 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-excl_area_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-excl_area-15">[B]</a></sup> making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_South_American_countries_by_area" title="List of South American countries by area">second-largest country in South America</a> after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, the fourth-largest country in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">eighth-largest country</a> in the world. It shares the bulk of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a> with <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> to the west, and is also bordered by <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> to the north, Brazil to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> and the South <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> to the east, and the <a href="/wiki/Drake_Passage" title="Drake Passage">Drake Passage</a> to the south. Argentina is a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federal state</a> subdivided into twenty-three <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Argentina" title="Provinces of Argentina">provinces</a>, and one <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_city" title="Autonomous city">autonomous city</a>, which is the <a href="/wiki/Federal_capital" title="Federal capital">federal capital</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Argentina_by_population" title="List of cities in Argentina by population">largest city</a> of the nation, <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>. The provinces and the capital have their own constitutions, but exist under a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal system</a>. Argentina claims sovereignty over <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Antarctica" title="Argentine Antarctica">a part of Antarctica</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" title="Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute">Falkland Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands sovereignty dispute">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>.
</p><p>The earliest recorded human presence in modern-day Argentina dates back to the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197117_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197117-22">[16]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Inca_Empire" title="Inca Empire">Inca Empire</a> expanded to the northwest of the country in Pre-Columbian times. The country has its roots in <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish colonization</a> of the region during the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992128_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992128-23">[17]</a></sup> Argentina rose as the successor state of the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata">Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevene194811Sánchez_Viamonte1948196–97Vanossi196411_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevene194811Sánchez_Viamonte1948196–97Vanossi196411-24">[18]</a></sup> a Spanish <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty" title="Viceroyalty">overseas viceroyalty</a> founded in 1776. The <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Argentine Declaration of Independence">declaration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Argentine_War_of_Independence" title="Argentine War of Independence">fight for independence</a> (1810–1818) was followed by an <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Civil_Wars" title="Argentine Civil Wars">extended civil war</a> that lasted until 1861, culminating in the country's reorganization as a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a>. The country thereafter enjoyed relative peace and stability, with <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Argentina" title="Immigration to Argentina">several waves of European immigration</a>, mainly <a href="/wiki/Italian_Argentines" title="Italian Argentines">Italians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Argentines" title="Spanish Argentines">Spaniards</a>, radically reshaping its <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Argentina" title="Culture of Argentina">cultural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Argentina" title="Demographics of Argentina">demographic</a> outlook; over 60% of the population has full or partial Italian ancestry,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LaMatanza_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-LaMatanza-26">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[21]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Argentina" title="Culture of Argentina">Argentine culture</a> has significant connections to <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Italy" title="Culture of Italy">Italian culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>The almost-unparalleled increase in prosperity led to Argentina becoming the seventh-wealthiest nation in the world by the early 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-29">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701-30">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[25]</a></sup> In 1896, Argentina's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP_per_capita" title="GDP per capita">GDP per capita</a> surpassed that of the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[26]</a></sup> and was consistently in the top ten before at least 1920.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[28]</a></sup> Currently, it is ranked <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">89th in the world</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> in the 1930s, Argentina descended into political instability and economic decline that pushed it back into underdevelopment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-developed_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-developed-35">[29]</a></sup> although it remained among the fifteen richest countries for several decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-29">[23]</a></sup> Following the death of President <a href="/wiki/Juan_Per%C3%B3n" title="Juan Perón">Juan Perón</a> in 1974, his widow and vice president, <a href="/wiki/Isabel_Per%C3%B3n" title="Isabel Perón">Isabel Perón</a>, ascended to the presidency, before being overthrown <a href="/wiki/1976_Argentine_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1976 Argentine coup d'état">in 1976</a>. The following <a href="/wiki/National_Reorganization_Process" title="National Reorganization Process">military junta</a>, which was supported by the United States, persecuted and murdered thousands of political critics, activists, and leftists in the <a href="/wiki/Dirty_War" title="Dirty War">Dirty War</a>, a period of <a href="/wiki/State_terrorism" title="State terrorism">state terrorism</a> and civil unrest that lasted until the election of <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Alfons%C3%ADn" title="Raúl Alfonsín">Raúl Alfonsín</a> as president in <a href="/wiki/1983_Argentine_general_election" title="1983 Argentine general election">1983</a>.
</p><p>Argentina is a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a>, and retains its historic status as a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> in international affairs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWood198818Solomon19973_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWood198818Solomon19973-36">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuntington20006Nierop200161Lake200955Papadopoulos2010283Malamud20119Boughton2012101_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuntington20006Nierop200161Lake200955Papadopoulos2010283Malamud20119Boughton2012101-37">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris198863AdlerGreve200978Ruiz-DanaGoldschagClaroBlanco200918_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris198863AdlerGreve200978Ruiz-DanaGoldschagClaroBlanco200918-38">[32]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">Major non-NATO ally</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Major_Non-NATO_Ally_Status_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Major_Non-NATO_Ally_Status-39">[33]</a></sup> Argentina is a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a> that ranks 46th in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, the second-highest in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> after <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>. It maintains the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Argentina" title="Economy of Argentina">second-largest economy</a> in South America, and is a member of <a href="/wiki/Group_of_15" title="Group of 15">G-15</a> and <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>. Argentina is also a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Latin_American_and_Caribbean_States" title="Community of Latin American and Caribbean States">Community of Latin American and Caribbean States</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The description of the region by the word <i>Argentina</i> has been found on a <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Venetian</a> map in 1536.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>In English, the name "Argentina" comes from the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish language</a>; however, the naming itself is not Spanish, but <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>. <i>Argentina</i> (<a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">masculine</a> <i>argentino</i>) means in Italian "(made) of silver, silver coloured", derived from the Latin "argentum" for silver. In Italian, the adjective or the <a href="/wiki/Proper_noun" title="Proper noun">proper noun</a> is often used in an autonomous way as a substantive and replaces it and it is said <i>l'Argentina</i>.
</p><p>The name <i>Argentina</i> was probably first given by the Venetian and Genoese navigators, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Giovanni_Caboto" title="Giovanni Caboto">Giovanni Caboto</a>. In Spanish and Portuguese, the words for "silver" are respectively <i>plata</i> and <i>prata</i> and "(made) of silver" is <i>plateado</i> and <i>prateado</i>. <i>Argentina</i> was first associated with the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_de_la_Plata" title="Sierra de la Plata">silver mountains legend</a>, widespread among the first European explorers of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Plata_Basin" title="La Plata Basin">La Plata Basin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERock19876,_8Edwards20087_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERock19876,_8Edwards20087-41">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first written use of the name in Spanish can be traced to <i><a href="/wiki/La_Argentina_(poem)" title="La Argentina (poem)">La Argentina</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[C]</a></sup> a 1602 poem by <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_del_Barco_Centenera" title="Martín del Barco Centenera">Martín del Barco Centenera</a> describing the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETraba198515,_71_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETraba198515,_71-43">[36]</a></sup> Although "Argentina" was already in common usage by the 18th century, the country was formally named "<a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata">Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata</a>" by the Spanish Empire, and "<a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="United Provinces of the Río de la Plata">United Provinces of the Río de la Plata</a>" after independence.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Constitution_of_1826" title="Argentine Constitution of 1826">1826 constitution</a> included the first use of the name "Argentine Republic" in legal documents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentina1826,_art._1_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentina1826,_art._1-44">[37]</a></sup> The name "Argentine Confederation" was also commonly used and was formalized in the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Constitution_of_1853" title="Argentine Constitution of 1853">Argentine Constitution of 1853</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentina1853,_Preamble_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentina1853,_Preamble-45">[38]</a></sup> In 1860 a presidential decree settled the country's name as "Argentine Republic",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERosenblat196478_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERosenblat196478-46">[39]</a></sup> and that year's constitutional amendment ruled all the names since 1810 as legally valid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentina1860_amd.,_art._35_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentina1860_amd.,_art._35-47">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[D]</a></sup>
</p><p>In English, the country was traditionally called "the Argentine", mimicking the typical Spanish usage <i>la Argentina</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[41]</a></sup> and perhaps resulting from a mistaken shortening of the fuller name 'Argentine Republic'. 'The Argentine' fell out of fashion during the mid-to-late 20th century, and now the country is simply referred to as "Argentina".
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Argentina" title="History of Argentina">History of Argentina</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Columbian_era">Pre-Columbian era</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Argentina" title="Indigenous peoples in Argentina">Indigenous peoples in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg/220px-SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg/330px-SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg/440px-SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Cueva_de_las_Manos" title="Cueva de las Manos">Cave of the Hands</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_province,_Argentina" title="Santa Cruz province, Argentina">Santa Cruz province</a>, with artwork dating from 13,000 to 9,000 years ago</div></div></div>
<p>The earliest traces of human life in the area now known as Argentina are dated from the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> period, with further traces in the <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197117_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197117-22">[16]</a></sup> Until the period of European colonization, Argentina was relatively sparsely populated by a wide number of diverse cultures with different social organizations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEdwards200812_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEdwards200812-50">[42]</a></sup> which can be divided into three main groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197118–19_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197118–19-51">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first group are basic hunters and food gatherers without development of <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">pottery</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Selk%27nam_people" title="Selk'nam people">Selknam</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yaghan_people" title="Yaghan people">Yaghan</a> in the extreme south. The second group are advanced hunters and food gatherers which include the <a href="/wiki/Puelche_people" title="Puelche people">Puelche</a>, <a href="/wiki/Querand%C3%AD" title="Querandí">Querandí</a> and Serranos in the centre-east; and the <a href="/wiki/Tehuelche_people" title="Tehuelche people">Tehuelche</a> in the south—all of them conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Mapuche" title="Mapuche">Mapuche</a> spreading from <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEdwards200813_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEdwards200813-52">[44]</a></sup>—and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kom_people_(South_America)" title="Kom people (South America)">Kom</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wichi" title="Wichi">Wichi</a> in the north. The last group are farmers with pottery, like the <a href="/wiki/Charr%C3%BAa" title="Charrúa">Charrúa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minuane" title="Minuane">Minuane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guaran%C3%AD_people" title="Guaraní people">Guaraní</a> in the northeast, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slash_and_burn_agriculture" title="Slash and burn agriculture">slash and burn</a> semisedentary existence;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEdwards200812_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEdwards200812-50">[42]</a></sup> the advanced <a href="/wiki/Diaguita" title="Diaguita">Diaguita</a> sedentary <a href="/wiki/Trade" title="Trade">trading culture</a> in the northwest, which was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Inca_Empire" title="Inca Empire">Inca Empire</a> around 1480; the <a href="/wiki/Toconot%C3%A9" title="Toconoté">Toconoté</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Comechingones" title="Comechingones">Hênîa and Kâmîare</a> in the country's centre, and the <a href="/wiki/Huarpe" title="Huarpe">Huarpe</a> in the centre-west, a culture that raised <a href="/wiki/Llama" title="Llama">llama</a> cattle and was strongly influenced by the Incas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEdwards200812_50-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEdwards200812-50">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_era">Colonial era</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Argentina" title="Colonial Argentina">Colonial Argentina</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">Spanish colonization of the Americas</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg"><img alt="Painting showing the surrender during the British invasions of the Río de la Plata." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="857" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/74/La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg/220px-La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/74/La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg/330px-La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/74/La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg/440px-La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_Reconquista_de_Buenos_Aires.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The surrender of Beresford to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santiago_de_Liniers" title="Santiago de Liniers">Santiago de Liniers</a> during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_invasions_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="British invasions of the Río de la Plata">British invasions of the Río de la Plata</a></div></div></div>
<p>Europeans first arrived in the region with the 1502 voyage of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci_(explorer)" title="Amerigo Vespucci (explorer)">Amerigo Vespucci</a>. The Spanish navigators <a href="/wiki/Juan_D%C3%ADaz_de_Sol%C3%ADs" title="Juan Díaz de Solís">Juan Díaz de Solís</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sebastian_Cabot_(explorer)" title="Sebastian Cabot (explorer)">Sebastian Cabot</a> visited the territory that is now Argentina in 1516 and 1526, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992128_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992128-23">[17]</a></sup> In 1536 <a href="/wiki/Pedro_de_Mendoza" title="Pedro de Mendoza">Pedro de Mendoza</a> founded the small settlement of <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, which was abandoned in 1541.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992129–32_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992129–32-53">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>Further colonization efforts came from <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>—establishing the <a href="/wiki/Governorate_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Governorate of the Río de la Plata">Governorate of the Río de la Plata</a>—<a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> and Chile.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197196–140_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán197196–140-54">[46]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Francisco_de_Aguirre_(conquistador)" title="Francisco de Aguirre (conquistador)">Francisco de Aguirre</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Santiago_del_Estero" title="Santiago del Estero">Santiago del Estero</a> in 1553. <a href="/wiki/Londres,_Catamarca" title="Londres, Catamarca">Londres</a> was founded in 1558; <a href="/wiki/Mendoza,_Argentina" title="Mendoza, Argentina">Mendoza</a>, in 1561; <a href="/wiki/San_Juan,_Argentina" title="San Juan, Argentina">San Juan</a>, in 1562; <a href="/wiki/San_Miguel_de_Tucum%C3%A1n" title="San Miguel de Tucumán">San Miguel de Tucumán</a>, in 1565.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992353_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992353-55">[47]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Garay" title="Juan de Garay">Juan de Garay</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe,_Argentina" title="Santa Fe, Argentina">Santa Fe</a> in 1573 and the same year <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimo_Luis_de_Cabrera" title="Jerónimo Luis de Cabrera">Jerónimo Luis de Cabrera</a> set up <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Argentina" title="Córdoba, Argentina">Córdoba</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992134_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992134-56">[48]</a></sup> Garay went further south to re-found Buenos Aires in 1580.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992135_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992135-57">[49]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/San_Luis,_Argentina" title="San Luis, Argentina">San Luis</a> was established in 1596.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992353_55-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992353-55">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> subordinated the economic potential of the Argentine territory to the immediate wealth of the silver and gold mines in <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and Peru, and as such it became part of the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru" title="Viceroyalty of Peru">Viceroyalty of Peru</a> until the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata">Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata</a> in 1776 with Buenos Aires as its capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992347_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992347-58">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buenos Aires repelled <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_invasions_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="British invasions of the Río de la Plata">two ill-fated British invasions</a> in 1806 and 1807.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1992421_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1992421-59">[51]</a></sup> The ideas of the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a> and the example of the first <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Revolutions" title="Atlantic Revolutions">Atlantic Revolutions</a> generated criticism of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Absolutist_monarchy" title="Absolutist monarchy">absolutist monarchy</a> that ruled the country. As in the rest of Spanish America, the overthrow of <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_VII_of_Spain" title="Ferdinand VII of Spain">Ferdinand VII</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_War" title="Peninsular War">Peninsular War</a> created great concern.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán1971194ff_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán1971194ff-60">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_and_civil_wars">Independence and civil wars</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Argentine_War_of_Independence" title="Argentine War of Independence">Argentine War of Independence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Civil_Wars" title="Argentine Civil Wars">Argentine Civil Wars</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_(retrato,_c.1828).jpg"><img alt="Painting of San Martín holding the Argentine flag" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1573" data-file-width="1199" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_%28retrato%2C_c.1828%29.jpg/170px-Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_%28retrato%2C_c.1828%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_%28retrato%2C_c.1828%29.jpg/255px-Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_%28retrato%2C_c.1828%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_%28retrato%2C_c.1828%29.jpg/340px-Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_%28retrato%2C_c.1828%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn_(retrato,_c.1828).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Portrait of General <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Martin" title="José de San Martin">José de San Martin</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Libertadores" title="Libertadores">Libertador</a></i> of Argentina, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Beginning a process from which Argentina was to emerge as successor state to the Viceroyalty,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevene194811Sánchez_Viamonte1948196–97Vanossi196411_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevene194811Sánchez_Viamonte1948196–97Vanossi196411-24">[18]</a></sup> the 1810 <a href="/wiki/May_Revolution" title="May Revolution">May Revolution</a> replaced the viceroy <a href="/wiki/Baltasar_Hidalgo_de_Cisneros" title="Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros">Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Primera_Junta" title="Primera Junta">First Junta</a>, a new government in Buenos Aires composed by locals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán1971194ff_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbad_de_Santillán1971194ff-60">[52]</a></sup> In the first clashes of the Independence War the Junta crushed a royalist <a href="/wiki/Liniers_Counter-revolution" title="Liniers Counter-revolution">counter-revolution in Córdoba</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERock198781_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERock198781-61">[53]</a></sup> but failed to overcome those of the <a href="/wiki/Banda_Oriental" title="Banda Oriental">Banda Oriental</a>, <a href="/wiki/First_Upper_Peru_campaign" title="First Upper Peru campaign">Upper Peru</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paraguay_campaign" title="Paraguay campaign">Paraguay</a>, which later became independent states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERock198782–83_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERock198782–83-62">[54]</a></sup> The French-Argentine <a href="/wiki/Hippolyte_Bouchard" title="Hippolyte Bouchard">Hippolyte Bouchard</a> then brought his fleet to wage war against Spain overseas and attacked Spanish California, Spanish Chile, Spanish Peru and Spanish Philippines. He secured the allegiance of escaped Filipinos in San Blas who defected from the Spanish to join the Argentine navy, due to common Argentine and Philippine grievances against Spanish colonization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[56]</a></sup> At a later date, the Argentine <a href="/wiki/Sun_of_May" title="Sun of May">Sun of May</a> was adopted as a symbol by the Filipinos in the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Biak-na-Bato" title="Republic of Biak-na-Bato">Philippine Revolution</a> against Spain. He also secured the diplomatic recognition of Argentina from King <a href="/wiki/Kamehameha_I" title="Kamehameha I">Kamehameha I</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hawaii" title="Kingdom of Hawaii">Kingdom of Hawaii</a>. Historian Pacho O'Donnell affirms that Hawaii was the first state that recognized Argentina's independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Donnell1998_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Donnell1998-65">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Revolutionaries split into two antagonist groups: the <a href="/wiki/Unitarian_Party" title="Unitarian Party">Centralists</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federales_(Argentina)" title="Federales (Argentina)">Federalists</a>—a move that would define Argentina's first decades of independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis200339–40_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis200339–40-66">[58]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_the_Year_XIII" title="Assembly of the Year XIII">Assembly of the Year XIII</a> appointed <a href="/wiki/Gervasio_Antonio_de_Posadas" title="Gervasio Antonio de Posadas">Gervasio Antonio de Posadas</a> as Argentina's first <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Director_of_the_United_Provinces_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Supreme Director of the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata">Supreme Director</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis200339–40_66-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis200339–40-66">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 9 July 1816, the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Tucum%C3%A1n" title="Congress of Tucumán">Congress of Tucumán</a> formalized the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Argentine Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERock198792Lewis200341_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERock198792Lewis200341-67">[59]</a></sup> which is now celebrated as Independence Day, a national holiday.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[60]</a></sup> One year later General <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Miguel_de_G%C3%BCemes" title="Martín Miguel de Güemes">Martín Miguel de Güemes</a> stopped royalists on the north, and General <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn" title="José de San Martín">José de San Martín</a> took an army <a href="/wiki/Crossing_of_the_Andes" title="Crossing of the Andes">across the Andes</a> and secured the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independence_of_Chile" title="Independence of Chile">independence of Chile</a>; then he led the fight to the Spanish stronghold of <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">Lima</a> and proclaimed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independence_of_Peru" title="Independence of Peru">independence of Peru</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011349–53vol._I_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011349–53vol._I-69">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[E]</a></sup> In 1819 Buenos Aires enacted a <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Constitution_of_1819" title="Argentine Constitution of 1819">centralist constitution</a> that was soon <a href="/wiki/Repeal" title="Repeal">abrogated</a> by federalists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis200341_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis200341-72">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the most important figures of Argentinean independence made a proposal known as the <a href="/wiki/Inca_plan" title="Inca plan">Inca plan</a> of 1816, which proposed that <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="United Provinces of the Río de la Plata">United Provinces of the Río de la Plata</a> (Present Argentina) should be a monarchy, led by a descendant of the <a href="/wiki/Sapa_Inca" title="Sapa Inca">Inca</a>. Juan Bautista Túpac Amaru (half-brother of <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BApac_Amaru_II" title="Túpac Amaru II">Túpac Amaru II</a>) was proposed as monarch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[64]</a></sup> Some examples of those who supported this proposal were <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Belgrano" title="Manuel Belgrano">Manuel Belgrano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_San_Mart%C3%ADn" title="José de San Martín">José de San Martín</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Miguel_de_G%C3%BCemes" title="Martín Miguel de Güemes">Martín Miguel de Güemes</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Tucum%C3%A1n" title="Congress of Tucumán">Congress of Tucumán</a> finally decided to reject the Inca plan, creating instead a republican, centralist state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1820 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cepeda_(1820)" title="Battle of Cepeda (1820)">Battle of Cepeda</a>, fought between the Centralists and the Federalists, resulted in the <i>end of the Supreme Director rule</i>. In 1826 Buenos Aires enacted another <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Constitution_of_1826" title="Argentine Constitution of 1826">centralist constitution</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Bernardino_Rivadavia" title="Bernardino Rivadavia">Bernardino Rivadavia</a> being appointed as the first president of the country. However, the interior provinces soon rose against him, forced his resignation and discarded the constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis200343_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis200343-76">[67]</a></sup> Centralists and Federalists resumed the civil war; the latter prevailed and formed the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Confederation" title="Argentine Confederation">Argentine Confederation</a> in 1831, led by <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_de_Rosas" title="Juan Manuel de Rosas">Juan Manuel de Rosas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis200345_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis200345-77">[68]</a></sup> During his regime he faced a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_blockade_to_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="French blockade to the Río de la Plata">French blockade</a> (1838–1840), the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Confederation" title="War of the Confederation">War of the Confederation</a> (1836–1839), and a combined <a href="/wiki/Anglo-French_blockade_of_the_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Anglo-French blockade of the Río de la Plata">Anglo-French blockade</a> (1845–1850), but remained undefeated and prevented further loss of national territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis200346–47_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis200346–47-78">[69]</a></sup> His trade restriction policies, however, angered the interior provinces and in 1852 <a href="/wiki/Justo_Jos%C3%A9_de_Urquiza" title="Justo José de Urquiza">Justo José de Urquiza</a>, another powerful <a href="/wiki/Caudillo" title="Caudillo">caudillo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Caseros" title="Battle of Caseros">beat him out of power</a>. As new president of the Confederation, Urquiza enacted the <a href="/wiki/Liberalism" title="Liberalism">liberal</a> and federal 1853 Constitution. <a href="/wiki/State_of_Buenos_Aires" title="State of Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires seceded</a> but was forced back into the Confederation after being defeated in the 1859 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cepeda_(1859)" title="Battle of Cepeda (1859)">Battle of Cepeda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis200348–50_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis200348–50-79">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rise_of_the_modern_nation">Rise of the modern nation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Argentina" title="List of Presidents of Argentina">List of Presidents of Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Generation_of_%2780" title="Generation of '80">Generation of '80</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Infamous_Decade" title="Infamous Decade">Infamous Decade</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Argentine%E2%80%93Chilean_naval_arms_race" title="Argentine–Chilean naval arms race">Argentine–Chilean naval arms race</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_American_dreadnought_race" title="South American dreadnought race">South American dreadnought race</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1036" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg/220px-25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg/330px-25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg/440px-25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:25_de_mayo_por_F._Fortuny.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>People gathered in front of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires_Cabildo" title="Buenos Aires Cabildo">Buenos Aires Cabildo</a> during the <a href="/wiki/May_Revolution" title="May Revolution">May Revolution</a></div></div></div>
<p>Overpowering Urquiza in the 1861 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Pav%C3%B3n" title="Battle of Pavón">Battle of Pavón</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bartolom%C3%A9_Mitre" title="Bartolomé Mitre">Bartolomé Mitre</a> secured Buenos Aires predominance and was elected as the first president of the reunified country. He was followed by <a href="/wiki/Domingo_Faustino_Sarmiento" title="Domingo Faustino Sarmiento">Domingo Faustino Sarmiento</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Avellaneda" title="Nicolás Avellaneda">Nicolás Avellaneda</a>; these three presidencies set up the basis of the modern Argentine State.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011363–541vol._I_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011363–541vol._I-80">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Starting with <a href="/wiki/Julio_Argentino_Roca" title="Julio Argentino Roca">Julio Argentino Roca</a> in 1880, ten consecutive federal governments emphasized <a href="/wiki/Economic_liberalism" title="Economic liberalism">liberal economic policies</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immigration_in_Argentina" title="Immigration in Argentina">massive wave of European immigration</a> they promoted—second only to the United States'—led to a near-reinvention of Argentine society and economy that by 1908 had placed the country as the seventh wealthiest<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_29-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-29">[23]</a></sup> developed nation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701-30">[24]</a></sup> in the world.
Driven by this <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">immigration</a> wave and decreasing mortality, the Argentine population grew fivefold and the economy 15-fold:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis199018–30_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis199018–30-81">[72]</a></sup> from 1870 to 1910 Argentina's <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a> exports went from 100,000 to 2,500,000 t (110,000 to 2,760,000 short tons) per year, while frozen beef exports increased from 25,000 to 365,000 t (28,000 to 402,000 short tons) per year,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMosk199088–89_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMosk199088–89-82">[73]</a></sup> placing Argentina as one of the world's top five exporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECruz199010_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECruz199010-83">[74]</a></sup> Its railway mileage rose from 503 to 31,104 km (313 to 19,327 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19702–3_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19702–3-84">[75]</a></sup> Fostered by a new <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Law_1420" title="Argentine Law 1420">public, compulsory, free and secular education</a> system, <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">literacy</a> quickly increased from 22% to 65%, a level higher than most <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin American</a> nations would reach even fifty years later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECruz199010_83-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECruz199010-83">[74]</a></sup> Furthermore, real <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP" title="GDP">GDP</a> grew so fast that despite the huge immigration influx, <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">per capita income</a> between 1862 and 1920 went from 67% of developed country levels to 100%:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19702–3_84-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19702–3-84">[75]</a></sup> In 1865, Argentina was already one of the top 25 nations by per capita income. By 1908, it had surpassed Denmark, Canada and the Netherlands to reach 7th place—behind Switzerland, New Zealand, Australia, the United States, the United Kingdom and Belgium. Argentina's per capita income was 70% higher than Italy's, 90% higher than Spain's, 180% higher than Japan's and 400% higher than <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>'s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_29-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-29">[23]</a></sup> Despite these unique achievements, the country was slow to meet its original goals of industrialization:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011567–625vol._I_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011567–625vol._I-85">[76]</a></sup> after steep development of capital-intensive local industries in the 1920s, a significant part of the manufacture sector remained labour-intensive in the 1930s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis199037–38_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis199037–38-86">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4092" data-file-width="2992" decoding="async" height="233" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg/170px-General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg/255px-General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg/340px-General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:General_Don_Julio_Argentino_Roca.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Julio_Argentino_Roca" title="Julio Argentino Roca">Julio Argentino Roca</a> was a major figure of the <a href="/wiki/Generation_of_%2780" title="Generation of '80">Generation of '80</a> and is known for directing the "<a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_the_Desert" title="Conquest of the Desert">Conquest of the Desert</a>". During his two terms as <a href="/wiki/President_of_Argentina" title="President of Argentina">President</a> many changes occurred, particularly major infrastructure projects of railroads; large-scale immigration from <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> and laicizing legislation strengthening state power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[78]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Between 1878 and 1884 the so-called <a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_the_Desert" title="Conquest of the Desert">Conquest of the Desert</a> occurred, with the purpose of giving by means of the constant confrontations between natives and Criollos in the border,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[79]</a></sup> and the appropriation of the indigenous territories, tripling the Argentine territory. The first conquest, consisted of a series of military incursions into the Pampa and Patagonian territories dominated by the indigenous peoples,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[80]</a></sup> distributing them among the members of the <i>Sociedad Rural Argentina</i>, financiers of the expeditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[81]</a></sup> The conquest of Chaco lasted up to the end of the century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[82]</a></sup> since its full ownership of the national economic system only took place when the mere extraction of wood and <a href="/wiki/Tannin" title="Tannin">tannin</a> was replaced by the production of <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[83]</a></sup> The Argentine government considered <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Argentina" title="Indigenous peoples in Argentina">indigenous people</a> as inferior beings, without the same rights as Criollos and Europeans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1912, President <a href="/wiki/Roque_S%C3%A1enz_Pe%C3%B1a" title="Roque Sáenz Peña">Roque Sáenz Peña</a> enacted <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saenz_Pe%C3%B1a_Law" title="Saenz Peña Law">universal and secret male suffrage</a>, which allowed <a href="/wiki/Hip%C3%B3lito_Yrigoyen" title="Hipólito Yrigoyen">Hipólito Yrigoyen</a>, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Radical_Civic_Union" title="Radical Civic Union">Radical Civic Union</a> (or UCR), to win <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1916" title="Argentine general election, 1916">the 1916 election</a>. He enacted social and economic reforms and extended assistance to small farms and businesses. Argentina stayed neutral during <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>. The second administration of Yrigoyen faced an economic crisis, precipitated by the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso20117–178vol._II_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso20117–178vol._II-94">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1930, Yrigoyen <a href="/wiki/1930_Argentine_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1930 Argentine coup d'état">was ousted from power</a> by the military led by <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_F%C3%A9lix_Uriburu" title="José Félix Uriburu">José Félix Uriburu</a>. Although Argentina remained among the fifteen richest countries until mid-century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_29-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-29">[23]</a></sup> this <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coup d'état</a> marks the start of the steady economic and social decline that pushed the country back into underdevelopment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-developed_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-developed-35">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>Uriburu ruled for two years; then <a href="/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_Pedro_Justo" title="Agustín Pedro Justo">Agustín Pedro Justo</a> was elected in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1931" title="Argentine general election, 1931">fraudulent election</a>, and signed a controversial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roca-Runciman_Treaty" title="Roca-Runciman Treaty">treaty with the United Kingdom</a>. Argentina <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentina_in_World_War_II" title="Argentina in World War II">stayed neutral during World War II</a>, a decision that had full British support but was rejected by the United States after the <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a>. In 1943 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revolution_of_%2743" title="Revolution of '43">a military coup d'état</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Rawson" title="Arturo Rawson">General Arturo Rawson</a> toppled the democratically elected government of <a href="/wiki/Ram%C3%B3n_Castillo" title="Ramón Castillo">Ramón Castillo</a>. Under pressure from the United States, later Argentina declared war on the Axis Powers (on 27 March 1945, roughly a month before the <a href="/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Europe" title="End of World War II in Europe">end of World War II in Europe</a>).
</p><p>During the Rawson dictatorship a relatively unknown military colonel named <a href="/wiki/Juan_Per%C3%B3n" title="Juan Perón">Juan Perón</a> was named head of the Labour Department. Perón quickly managed to climb the political ladder, being named Ministry of Defence by 1944. Being perceived as a political threat by rivals in the military and the conservative camp, he was forced to resign in 1945, and was arrested days later. He was finally released under mounting pressure from both his base and several allied unions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011181–302vol._II_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011181–302vol._II-95">[86]</a></sup> He would later become president after a landslide victory over the <a href="/wiki/Radical_Civic_Union" title="Radical Civic Union">UCR</a> in the <a href="/wiki/1946_Argentine_general_election" title="1946 Argentine general election">1946 general election</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(Argentina)" title="Labour Party (Argentina)">Laborioust</a> candidate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Peronist_years">Peronist years</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Peronism" title="Peronism">Peronism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg"><img alt="Juan Domingo Perón and his wife Eva Perón, 1947." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="529" data-file-width="487" decoding="async" height="239" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg/220px-Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg/330px-Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg/440px-Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Juan_y_Eva_Oficial.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Juan_Per%C3%B3n" title="Juan Perón">Juan Perón</a> and his wife <a href="/wiki/Eva_Per%C3%B3n" title="Eva Perón">Eva Perón</a>, 1947</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(Argentina)" title="Labour Party (Argentina)">Labour Party</a> (later renamed <a href="/wiki/Justicialist_Party" title="Justicialist Party">Justicialist Party</a>), the most powerful and influential party in Argentine history, came into power with the rise of Juan Perón to the presidency in 1946. He <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">nationalized</a> strategic industries and services, improved wages and working conditions, paid the full <a href="/wiki/External_debt" title="External debt">external debt</a> and claimed he achieved nearly <a href="/wiki/Full_employment" title="Full employment">full employment</a>. He pushed Congress to enact <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage" title="Women's suffrage">women's suffrage</a> in 1947,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarnes19783_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarnes19783-97">[88]</a></sup> and developed a system of social assistance for the most vulnerable sectors of society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarnes1978113ff_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarnes1978113ff-98">[89]</a></sup> The economy began to decline in 1950 due in part to government expenditures and the <a href="/wiki/Protectionism" title="Protectionism">protectionist</a> economic policies.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>He also engaged in a campaign of political suppression. Anyone who was perceived to be a political dissident or potential rival was subject to threats, physical violence and harassment. The Argentine <a href="/wiki/Intelligentsia" title="Intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a>, the middle-class, university students, and professors were seen as particularly troublesome. Perón fired over 2,000 university professors and faculty members from all major public education institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auth_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-auth-99">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>Perón tried to bring most trade and labour unions under his thumb, regularly resorting to violence when needed. For instance, the meat-packers union leader, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cipriano_Reyes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cipriano Reyes (page does not exist)">Cipriano Reyes</a>, organised strikes in protest against the government after elected labour movement officials were forcefully replaced by Peronist puppets from the <a href="/wiki/Justicialist_Party" title="Justicialist Party">Peronist Party</a>. Reyes was soon arrested on charges of terrorism, though the allegations were never substantiated. Reyes,who was never formally charged, was tortured in prison for five years and only released after the regime's downfall in 1955.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>Perón <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1951" title="Argentine general election, 1951">managed to get reelected in 1951</a>. His wife <a href="/wiki/Eva_Per%C3%B3n" title="Eva Perón">Eva Perón</a>, who played a critical role in the party, died of cancer in 1952. As the economy continued to tank, Perón started losing popular support, and came to be seen as a threat to the national process. The Navy took advantage of Perón's withering political power, and <a href="/wiki/Bombing_of_Plaza_de_Mayo" title="Bombing of Plaza de Mayo">bombed the Plaza de Mayo</a> in 1955. Perón survived the attack, but a few months later, during the <a href="/wiki/Revoluci%C3%B3n_Libertadora" title="Revolución Libertadora">Liberating Revolution</a> coup, he was deposed and went into <a href="/wiki/Exile" title="Exile">exile</a> in Spain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011303–51vol._II_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011303–51vol._II-101">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Revoluci.C3.B3n_Libertadora"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Revolución_Libertadora">Revolución Libertadora</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Revoluci%C3%B3n_Libertadora" title="Revolución Libertadora">Revolución Libertadora</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="365" data-file-width="584" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG/220px-Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG/330px-Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG/440px-Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Plaza-Mayo-bombardeo-1955.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Civilian casualties after the <a href="/wiki/Bombing_of_Plaza_de_Mayo" title="Bombing of Plaza de Mayo">air attack and massacre on Plaza de Mayo</a>, June 1955</div></div></div>
<p>The new head of State, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Eugenio_Aramburu" title="Pedro Eugenio Aramburu">Pedro Eugenio Aramburu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Proscription" title="Proscription">proscribed</a> Peronism and banned the party from any future elections. <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Frondizi" title="Arturo Frondizi">Arturo Frondizi</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Radical_Civic_Union" title="Radical Civic Union">UCR</a> won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1958" title="Argentine general election, 1958">1958 general election</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011353–379vol._II_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011353–379vol._II-102">[93]</a></sup> He encouraged investment to achieve energetic and industrial self-sufficiency, reversed a chronic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_deficit" title="Trade deficit">trade deficit</a> and lifted the ban on Peronism; yet his efforts to stay on good terms with both the Peronists and the military earned him the rejection of both and a new coup forced him out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobben201134_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobben201134-103">[94]</a></sup> Amidst the political turmoil, Senate leader <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Guido" title="José María Guido">José María Guido</a> reacted swiftly and applied anti-<a href="/wiki/Power_vacuum" title="Power vacuum">power vacuum</a> legislation, ascending to the presidency himself; elections were repealed and Peronism was prohibited once again. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arturo_Illia" title="Arturo Illia">Arturo Illia</a> was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1963" title="Argentine general election, 1963">elected in 1963</a> and led an increase in prosperity across the board; however he was overthrown in 1966 by another military <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coup d'état</a> led by General <a href="/wiki/Juan_Carlos_Ongan%C3%ADa" title="Juan Carlos Onganía">Juan Carlos Onganía</a> in the self-proclaimed <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Revolution" title="Argentine Revolution">Argentine Revolution</a>, creating a new military government that sought to rule indefinitely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011381–422vol._II_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011381–422vol._II-104">[95]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Per.C3.B3n.27s_return_and_death"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Perón's_return_and_death">Perón's return and death</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n,_1973.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="447" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="190" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n%2C_1973.png/170px-Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n%2C_1973.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n%2C_1973.png/255px-Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n%2C_1973.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n%2C_1973.png/340px-Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n%2C_1973.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Asunci%C3%B3n_de_Juan_Domingo_Per%C3%B3n_e_Isabel_Per%C3%B3n,_1973.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Juan_Per%C3%B3n" title="Juan Perón">Juan Perón</a> and his wife <a href="/wiki/Isabel_Per%C3%B3n" title="Isabel Perón">Isabel Perón</a>, 1973</div></div></div>
<p>Following several years of military rule, <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Agust%C3%ADn_Lanusse" title="Alejandro Agustín Lanusse">Alejandro Agustín Lanusse</a> was appointed president by the <a href="/wiki/Military_junta" title="Military junta">military junta</a> in 1971. Under increasing political pressure for the return of democracy, Lanusse called for elections in 1973. Perón was banned from running but the Peronist party was allowed to participate. The presidential elections were won by Perón's surrogate candidate, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hector_C%C3%A1mpora" title="Hector Cámpora">Hector Cámpora</a>, a left-wing Peronist, who took office on 25 May 1973. A month later, in June, Perón returned from Spain. One of Cámpora's first presidential actions was to grant amnesty to members of organizations that had carried out political assassinations and terrorist attacks, and to those who had been tried and sentenced to prison by judges. Cámpora's months-long tenure in government was beset by political and social unrest. Over 600 social conflicts, <a href="/wiki/Strike_action" title="Strike action">strikes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_self-management" title="Workers' self-management">factory occupations</a> took place within a single month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[96]</a></sup> Even though far-left terrorist organisations had suspended their armed struggle, their joining with the <a href="/wiki/Participatory_democracy" title="Participatory democracy">participatory democracy</a> process was interpreted as a direct threat by the Peronist right-wing faction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>Amid a state of political, social, and economic upheaval, Cámpora and Vice President Vicente Solano Lima resigned in July 1973, calling for new elections, but this time with Perón as the Justicialist Party nominee. Perón won the election with his wife <a href="/wiki/Isabel_Per%C3%B3n" title="Isabel Perón">Isabel Perón</a> as vice president. Perón's third term was marked by escalating conflict between left and right-wing factions within the Peronist party, as well as the return of armed terror guerrilla groups like the Guevarist <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Revolutionary_Army_(Argentina)" title="People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)">ERP</a>, leftist Peronist <a href="/wiki/Montoneros" title="Montoneros">Montoneros</a>, and the state-backed far-right <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Anticommunist_Alliance" title="Argentine Anticommunist Alliance">Triple A</a>. After a series of heart attacks and with signs of pneumonia in 1974, Perón's health deteriorated quickly. He suffered a final heart attack on Monday, 1 July 1974, and died at 13:15. He was 78 years old. After his death, <a href="/wiki/Isabel_Per%C3%B3n" title="Isabel Perón">Isabel Perón</a>, his wife and vice president, succeeded him in office. During her presidency, a military junta, along with the Peronists' far-right fascist faction, once again became the <a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a> <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>. Isabel Perón served as President of Argentina from 1974 until 1976, when she was ousted by the military. Her short presidency was marked by the collapse of Argentine political and social systems, leading to a constitutional crisis that paved the way for a decade of instability, left-wing terrorist guerrilla attacks, and state-sponsored terrorism.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="National_Reorganization_Process">National Reorganization Process</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/National_Reorganization_Process" title="National Reorganization Process">National Reorganization Process</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dirty_War" title="Dirty War">Dirty War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="370" data-file-width="597" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png/220px-Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png/330px-Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png/440px-Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Junta_Militar_argentina_1976.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Admiral <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Eduardo_Massera" title="Emilio Eduardo Massera">Emilio Massera</a>, Lieutenant General <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Rafael_Videla" title="Jorge Rafael Videla">Jorge Videla</a> and Brigadier General <a href="/wiki/Orlando_Ram%C3%B3n_Agosti" title="Orlando Ramón Agosti">Orlando Agosti</a> (from left to right) – observing the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Argentine Declaration of Independence">Independence Day</a> military parade on <a href="/wiki/Avenida_del_Libertador_(Buenos_Aires)" title="Avenida del Libertador (Buenos Aires)">Avenida del Libertador</a>, 9 July 1978</div></div></div>
<p>The "Dirty War" (Spanish: <i lang="es">Guerra Sucia</i>) was part of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Condor" title="Operation Condor">Operation Condor</a>, which included the participation of other right-wing dictatorships in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a>. The Dirty War involved <a href="/wiki/State_terrorism" title="State terrorism">state terrorism</a> in Argentina and elsewhere in the Southern Cone against political dissidents, with military and security forces employing urban and rural violence against left-wing guerrillas, political dissidents, and anyone believed to be associated with socialism or somehow contrary to the <a href="/wiki/Neoliberalism" title="Neoliberalism">neoliberal</a> economic policies of the regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[100]</a></sup> Victims of the violence in Argentina alone included an estimated 15,000 to 30,000 left-wing activists and militants, including trade unionists, students, journalists, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxist" title="Marxist">Marxists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peronism" title="Peronism">Peronist</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guerrilla" title="Guerrilla">guerrillas</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[101]</a></sup> and alleged sympathizers. Most of the victims were casualties of <a href="/wiki/State_terrorism" title="State terrorism">state terrorism</a>. The opposing guerrillas' victims numbered nearly 500–540 military and police officials<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[102]</a></sup> and up to 230 civilians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[103]</a></sup> Argentina received technical support and military aid from the United States government during the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Presidency of Lyndon B. Johnson">Johnson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Richard_Nixon" title="Presidency of Richard Nixon">Nixon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Gerald_Ford" title="Presidency of Gerald Ford">Ford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Jimmy_Carter" title="Presidency of Jimmy Carter">Carter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Ronald_Reagan" title="Presidency of Ronald Reagan">Reagan</a> administrations.
</p><p>The exact chronology of the <a href="/wiki/Political_repression" title="Political repression">repression</a> is still debated, yet the roots of the long political war may have started in 1969 when trade unionists were targeted for assassination by Peronist and Marxist paramilitaries. Individual cases of <a href="/wiki/State-sponsored_terrorism" title="State-sponsored terrorism">state-sponsored terrorism</a> against Peronism and the left can be traced back even further to the <a href="/wiki/Bombing_of_Plaza_de_Mayo" title="Bombing of Plaza de Mayo">Bombing of Plaza de Mayo</a> in 1955. The <a href="/wiki/Trelew_massacre" title="Trelew massacre">Trelew massacre</a> of 1972, the actions of the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Anticommunist_Alliance" title="Argentine Anticommunist Alliance">Argentine Anticommunist Alliance</a> commencing in 1973, and <a href="/wiki/Isabel_Per%C3%B3n" title="Isabel Perón">Isabel Perón</a>'s "annihilation decrees" against left-wing guerrillas during <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operativo_Independencia" title="Operativo Independencia">Operativo Independencia</a></i> (Operation Independence) in 1975, are also possible events signaling the beginning of the Dirty War.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Onganía shut down Congress, banned all political parties, and dismantled student and worker unions. In 1969, popular discontent led to two massive protests: the <i><a href="/wiki/Cordobazo" title="Cordobazo">Cordobazo</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Rosariazo" title="Rosariazo">Rosariazo</a></i>. The terrorist guerrilla organization <a href="/wiki/Montoneros" title="Montoneros">Montoneros</a> kidnapped and executed Aramburu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobben2011127_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobben2011127-113">[104]</a></sup> The newly chosen head of government, <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Agust%C3%ADn_Lanusse" title="Alejandro Agustín Lanusse">Alejandro Agustín Lanusse</a>, seeking to ease the growing political pressure, allowed <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Jos%C3%A9_C%C3%A1mpora" title="Héctor José Cámpora">Héctor José Cámpora</a> to become the Peronist candidate instead of Perón. Cámpora won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_March_1973" title="Argentine general election, March 1973">March 1973 election</a>, issued <a href="/wiki/Amnesty" title="Amnesty">pardons</a> for condemned guerrilla members, and then secured Perón's return from his exile in Spain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011423–65vol._II_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011423–65vol._II-114">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
