<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Soldadosargentinos3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1638" data-file-width="1343" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Soldadosargentinos3.jpg/170px-Soldadosargentinos3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Soldadosargentinos3.jpg/255px-Soldadosargentinos3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Soldadosargentinos3.jpg/340px-Soldadosargentinos3.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Soldadosargentinos3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Argentinians soldiers during the <a href="/wiki/Falklands_War" title="Falklands War">Falklands War</a></div></div></div>
<p>On the day Perón returned to Argentina, the clash between Peronist internal factions—<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Right-wing" title="Right-wing">right-wing</a> union leaders and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Left-wing" title="Left-wing">left-wing</a> youth from the Montoneros—resulted in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ezeiza_Massacre" title="Ezeiza Massacre">Ezeiza Massacre</a>. Overwhelmed by political violence, Cámpora resigned and Perón won the following <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_September_1973" title="Argentine general election, September 1973">September 1973 election</a> with his third wife <a href="/wiki/Isabel_Per%C3%B3n" title="Isabel Perón">Isabel</a> as vice-president. He <a href="/wiki/Expulsion_of_Montoneros_from_Plaza_de_Mayo" title="Expulsion of Montoneros from Plaza de Mayo">expelled Montoneros from the party</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobben201176–77_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobben201176–77-115">[106]</a></sup> and they became once again a clandestine organization. <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_L%C3%B3pez_Rega" title="José López Rega">José López Rega</a> organized the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Anticommunist_Alliance" title="Argentine Anticommunist Alliance">Argentine Anticommunist Alliance</a> (AAA) to fight against them and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Revolutionary_Army_(Argentina)" title="People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)">People's Revolutionary Army</a> (ERP).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Perón died in July 1974 and was succeeded by his wife, who signed a secret decree empowering the military and the police to "annihilate" the left-wing subversion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobben2011145_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobben2011145-116">[107]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Operation_Independence" title="Operation Independence">stopping ERP's attempt</a> to start a rural insurgence in Tucumán province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobben2011148_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobben2011148-117">[108]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/March_1976_coup" title="March 1976 coup">Isabel Perón was ousted</a> one year later by a junta of the combined armed forces, led by army general <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Rafael_Videla" title="Jorge Rafael Videla">Jorge Rafael Videla</a>. They initiated the <a href="/wiki/National_Reorganization_Process" title="National Reorganization Process">National Reorganization Process</a>, often shortened to <i>Proceso</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011467–504vol._II_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011467–504vol._II-118">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i>Proceso</i> shut down Congress, removed the judges on the Supreme Court, banned political parties and unions, and resorted to employing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forced_disappearance" title="Forced disappearance">forced disappearance</a> of suspected guerrilla members including individuals suspected of being associated with the left-wing. By the end of 1976, the Montoneros had lost nearly 2,000 members and by 1977, the ERP was completely subdued. Nevertheless, the severely weakened Montoneros launched a counterattack in 1979, which was quickly put down, effectively ending the guerrilla threat and securing the junta's position in power.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In 1982, the head of state, General <a href="/wiki/Leopoldo_Galtieri" title="Leopoldo Galtieri">Leopoldo Galtieri</a>, authorised the invasion of the British territories of South Georgia and, on 2 April, of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Rosario" title="Operation Rosario">Falkland Islands</a>. The occupation provoked a military response from the United Kingdom leading to the <a href="/wiki/Falklands_War" title="Falklands War">Falklands War</a>. Argentine forces were defeated and surrendered to British troops on 14 June. Street riots in Buenos Aires followed the defeat<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[110]</a></sup> and the military leadership responsible for the humiliation withdrew.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[111]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Reynaldo_Bignone" title="Reynaldo Bignone">Reynaldo Bignone</a> replaced Galtieri and began to organize the transition to democratic governance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011505–32vol._II_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011505–32vol._II-121">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Return_to_democracy">Return to democracy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Ra%C3%BAl_Alfons%C3%ADn" title="Presidency of Raúl Alfonsín">Presidency of Raúl Alfonsín</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_economic_crisis_(1999%E2%80%932002)" title="Argentine economic crisis (1999–2002)">Argentine economic crisis (1999–2002)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg"><img alt="Photograph of the Argentine Constitution." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1880" data-file-width="2816" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg/220px-Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg/330px-Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg/440px-Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Two members of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regiment_of_Mounted_Grenadiers" title="Regiment of Mounted Grenadiers">Regiment of Mounted Grenadiers</a> guarding the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Argentina" title="Constitution of Argentina">Constitution of the Argentine Nation</a> inside the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Argentine_National_Congress" title="Palace of the Argentine National Congress">Palace of the Congress</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Alfons%C3%ADn" title="Raúl Alfonsín">Raúl Alfonsín</a> won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1983" title="Argentine general election, 1983">1983 elections</a> campaigning for the prosecution of those responsible for <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a> violations during the <i>Proceso</i>: the <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_the_Juntas" title="Trial of the Juntas">Trial of the Juntas</a> and other martial courts sentenced all the coup's leaders but, under military pressure, he also enacted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Full_Stop_Law" title="Full Stop Law">Full Stop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Due_Obedience" title="Law of Due Obedience">Due Obedience</a> laws,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[114]</a></sup> which halted prosecutions further down the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chain_of_command" title="Chain of command">chain of command</a>. The worsening economic crisis and <a href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflation</a> reduced his popular support and the Peronist <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Menem" title="Carlos Menem">Carlos Menem</a> won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1989" title="Argentine general election, 1989">1989 election</a>. Soon after, <a href="/wiki/1989_riots_in_Argentina" title="1989 riots in Argentina">riots forced Alfonsín to an early resignation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011533–49vol._II_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011533–49vol._II-124">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Menem embraced and enacted <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neo-liberalism" title="Neo-liberalism">neoliberal</a> policies:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20066_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20066-125">[116]</a></sup> a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_Currency_Board" title="Argentine Currency Board">fixed exchange rate</a>, business <a href="/wiki/Deregulation" title="Deregulation">deregulation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">privatizations</a>, and the dismantling of <a href="/wiki/Protectionism" title="Protectionism">protectionist</a> barriers normalized the economy in the short term. He pardoned the officers who had been sentenced during Alfonsín's government. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1994_amendment_of_the_Argentine_Constitution" title="1994 amendment of the Argentine Constitution">1994 Constitutional Amendment</a> allowed Menem to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1995" title="Argentine general election, 1995">be elected for a second term</a>. With the economy beginning to decline in 1995, and with increasing unemployment and recession,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069-126">[117]</a></sup> the UCR, led by <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_la_R%C3%BAa" title="Fernando de la Rúa">Fernando de la Rúa</a>, returned to the presidency in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1999" title="Argentine general election, 1999">1999 elections</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011551–573vol._II_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011551–573vol._II-127">[118]</a></sup>
</p><p>De la Rúa left Menem's economic plan in effect despite the worsening crisis, which led to growing social discontent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069-126">[117]</a></sup> Massive <a href="/wiki/Capital_flight" title="Capital flight">capital flight</a> from the country was responded to with a <a href="/wiki/Corralito" title="Corralito">freezing of bank accounts</a>, generating further turmoil. The <a href="/wiki/December_2001_riots_in_Argentina" title="December 2001 riots in Argentina">December 2001 riots</a> forced him to resign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011575–87vol._II_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011575–87vol._II-128">[119]</a></sup> Congress appointed <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Duhalde" title="Eduardo Duhalde">Eduardo Duhalde</a> as acting president, who revoked the fixed exchange rate established by Menem,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200612_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200612-129">[120]</a></sup> causing many working- and middle-class Argentines to lose a significant portion of their savings. By late 2002, the economic crisis began to recede, but the assassination of two <i><a href="/wiki/Piquetero" title="Piquetero">piqueteros</a></i> by the police caused political unrest, prompting Duhalde to move elections forward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613-130">[121]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner" title="Néstor Kirchner">Néstor Kirchner</a> was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2003" title="Argentine general election, 2003">elected as the new president</a>. On 26 May 2003, he was sworn in.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011587–95vol._II_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011587–95vol._II-132">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1632" data-file-width="1450" decoding="async" height="191" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg/170px-Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg/255px-Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg/340px-Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cristina_con_baston_de_mando.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner" title="Néstor Kirchner">Néstor Kirchner</a> and his wife and political successor, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cristina_Kirchner" title="Cristina Kirchner">Cristina Kirchner</a></div></div></div>
<p>Boosting the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neo-Keynesianism" title="Neo-Keynesianism">neo-Keynesian</a> economic policies<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613_130-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613-130">[121]</a></sup> laid by Duhalde, Kirchner ended the economic crisis attaining significant fiscal and trade surpluses, and rapid <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200616_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200616-133">[124]</a></sup> Under his administration, Argentina <a href="/wiki/Argentine_debt_restructuring" title="Argentine debt restructuring">restructured its defaulted debt</a> with an unprecedented discount of about 70% on most bonds, paid off debts with the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200615_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200615-134">[125]</a></sup> purged the military of officers with dubious human rights records,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200614_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200614-135">[126]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Void_(law)" title="Void (law)">nullified and voided</a> the Full Stop and Due Obedience laws,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[F]</a></sup> ruled them as unconstitutional, and resumed legal prosecution of the Junta's crimes. He did not run for reelection, promoting instead the candidacy of his wife, senator <a href="/wiki/Cristina_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Kirchner" title="Cristina Fernández de Kirchner">Cristina Fernández de Kirchner</a>, who was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2007" title="Argentine general election, 2007">elected in 2007</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011597–626vol._II_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011597–626vol._II-139">[129]</a></sup> and subsequently <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2011" title="Argentine general election, 2011">reelected in 2011</a>. Fernández de Kirchner's administration established positive foreign relations with countries with questionable human rights records, including Venezuela, Iran, and Cuba, while at the same time relations with the United States and United Kingdom became increasingly strained. By 2015, the Argentine GDP grew by 2.7%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[130]</a></sup> and real incomes had risen over 50% since the post-Menem era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[131]</a></sup> Despite these economic gains and increased renewable energy production and subsidies, the overall economy had been sluggish since 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 22 November 2015, after a tie in the first round of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2015" title="Argentine general election, 2015">presidential elections on 25 October</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juntos_por_el_Cambio" title="Juntos por el Cambio">center-right coalition</a> candidate <a href="/wiki/Mauricio_Macri" title="Mauricio Macri">Mauricio Macri</a> won the first <a href="/wiki/Ballotage_in_Argentina" title="Ballotage in Argentina">ballotage</a> in Argentina's history, beating <a href="/wiki/Front_for_Victory" title="Front for Victory">Front for Victory</a> candidate <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Scioli" title="Daniel Scioli">Daniel Scioli</a> and becoming president-elect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[133]</a></sup> Macri was the first democratically elected non-<a href="/wiki/Justicialist_Party" title="Justicialist Party">peronist</a> president since 1916 that managed to complete his term in office without being overthrown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[134]</a></sup> He took office on 10 December 2015 and inherited an economy with a high inflation rate and in a poor shape.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[135]</a></sup> In April 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Mauricio_Macri" title="Presidency of Mauricio Macri">Macri Government</a> introduced neoliberal austerity measures intended to tackle <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a> and overblown public deficits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[136]</a></sup> Under Macri's administration, economic recovery remained elusive with GDP shrinking 3.4%, inflation totaling 240%, billions of US dollars issued in sovereign debt, and mass poverty increasing by the end of his term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[138]</a></sup> He ran for re-election in 2019 but lost by nearly eight percentage points to <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Fern%C3%A1ndez" title="Alberto Fernández">Alberto Fernández</a>, the Justicialist Party candidate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>President Alberto Fernández and Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner took office in December 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[140]</a></sup> just months before the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Argentina" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Argentina">COVID-19 pandemic hit Argentina</a> and among accusations of <a href="/wiki/Corruption" title="Corruption">corruption</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bribery" title="Bribery">bribery</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Route_of_the_K-Money" title="The Route of the K-Money">misuse of public funds during Nestor and Cristina Fernández de Kirchner's presidencies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mercopress_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mercopress-152">[142]</a></sup> On 14 November 2021, the center-left coalition of Argentina's ruling Peronist party,  <a href="/wiki/Frente_de_Todos" title="Frente de Todos">Frente de Todos</a> (Front for Everyone), lost its majority in Congress, for the first time in almost 40 years, in midterm <a href="/wiki/2021_Argentine_legislative_election" title="2021 Argentine legislative election">legislative elections</a>. The election victory of the center-right coalition, <a href="/wiki/Juntos_por_el_Cambio" title="Juntos por el Cambio">Juntos por el Cambio</a> (Together for Change), meant a tough final two years in office for President Alberto Fernandez. Losing control of the Senate made it difficult for him to make key appointments, including to the judiciary. It also forced him to negotiate with the opposition every initiative he sends to the legislature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Argentina" title="Geography of Argentina">Geography of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aconcagua_-_panoramio_(1).jpg"><img alt="Mountain tops, with clouds shown." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Aconcagua_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg/220px-Aconcagua_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Aconcagua_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg/330px-Aconcagua_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Aconcagua_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg/440px-Aconcagua_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aconcagua_-_panoramio_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Aconcagua" title="Aconcagua">Aconcagua</a> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extremes_of_Altitude" title="Extremes of Altitude">highest mountain</a> outside of Asia, at 6,960.8 metres (22,837 ft), and the highest point in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNC-Sigma_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNC-Sigma-155">[145]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>With a mainland surface area of 2,780,400 km<sup>2</sup> (1,073,518 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-excl_area_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-excl_area-15">[B]</a></sup> Argentina is located in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">southern South America</a>, sharing land borders with Chile across the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a> to the west;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[146]</a></sup> Bolivia and Paraguay to the north; Brazil to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Atlantic_Ocean" title="South Atlantic Ocean">South Atlantic Ocean</a> to the east;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igngeo_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-157">[147]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Drake_Passage" title="Drake Passage">Drake Passage</a> to the south;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcKinney19936FearnsFearns200531_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcKinney19936FearnsFearns200531-158">[148]</a></sup> for an overall land border length of 9,376 km (5,826 mi). Its coastal border over the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Río de la Plata">Río de la Plata</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Atlantic_Ocean" title="South Atlantic Ocean">South Atlantic Ocean</a> is 5,117 km (3,180 mi) long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igngeo_157-1"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-157">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina's highest point is <a href="/wiki/Aconcagua" title="Aconcagua">Aconcagua</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mendoza_province" title="Mendoza province">Mendoza province</a> (6,959 m (22,831 ft) above sea level),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ignmax_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-ignmax-159">[149]</a></sup> also the highest point in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western Hemispheres</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200552_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200552-160">[150]</a></sup> The lowest point is <a href="/wiki/Laguna_del_Carb%C3%B3n" title="Laguna del Carbón">Laguna del Carbón</a> in the <i>San Julián Great Depression</i> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_province,_Argentina" title="Santa Cruz province, Argentina">Santa Cruz province</a> (−105 m (−344 ft) below sea level,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ignmax_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-ignmax-159">[149]</a></sup> also the lowest point in the Southern and Western Hemispheres, and the seventh lowest point on Earth)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>The northernmost point is at the confluence of the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Grande_de_San_Juan" title="Río Grande de San Juan">Grande de San Juan</a> and Mojinete rivers in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jujuy_province" title="Jujuy province">Jujuy province</a>; the southernmost is <a href="/wiki/Cape_San_P%C3%ADo" title="Cape San Pío">Cape San Pío</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego_province,_Argentina" title="Tierra del Fuego province, Argentina">Tierra del Fuego province</a>; the easternmost is northeast of <a href="/wiki/Bernardo_de_Irigoyen,_Misiones" title="Bernardo de Irigoyen, Misiones">Bernardo de Irigoyen, Misiones</a> and the westernmost is within <a href="/wiki/Los_Glaciares_National_Park" title="Los Glaciares National Park">Los Glaciares National Park</a> in Santa Cruz province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igngeo_157-2"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-157">[147]</a></sup> The maximum north–south distance is 3,694 km (2,295 mi), while the maximum east–west one is 1,423 km (884 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igngeo_157-3"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-157">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the major rivers are the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paraná River">Paraná</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_River" title="Uruguay River">Uruguay</a>—which join to form the Río de la Plata, <a href="/wiki/Paraguay_River" title="Paraguay River">Paraguay</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salado_River,_Argentina" title="Salado River, Argentina">Salado</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Negro_River,_Argentina" title="Río Negro River, Argentina">Negro</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_River,_Argentina" title="Santa Cruz River, Argentina">Santa Cruz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pilcomayo_River" title="Pilcomayo River">Pilcomayo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bermejo_River" title="Bermejo River">Bermejo</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colorado_River,_Argentina" title="Colorado River, Argentina">Colorado</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20065,_7–8,_51,_175_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20065,_7–8,_51,_175-162">[152]</a></sup> These rivers are discharged into the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Sea" title="Argentine Sea">Argentine Sea</a>, the shallow area of the Atlantic Ocean over the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_Shelf" title="Argentine Shelf">Argentine Shelf</a>, an unusually wide <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Continental_platform" title="Continental platform">continental platform</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20068_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20068-163">[153]</a></sup> Its waters are influenced by two major ocean currents: the warm <a href="/wiki/Brazil_Current" title="Brazil Current">Brazil Current</a> and the cold <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Falklands_Current" title="Falklands Current">Falklands Current</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200618_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200618-164">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_Argentina" title="Environment of Argentina">Environment of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rufous_hornero_(Red_ovenbird)(Furnarius_rufus).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2929" data-file-width="4394" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Rufous_hornero_%28Red_ovenbird%29%28Furnarius_rufus%29.JPG/220px-Rufous_hornero_%28Red_ovenbird%29%28Furnarius_rufus%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Rufous_hornero_%28Red_ovenbird%29%28Furnarius_rufus%29.JPG/330px-Rufous_hornero_%28Red_ovenbird%29%28Furnarius_rufus%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Rufous_hornero_%28Red_ovenbird%29%28Furnarius_rufus%29.JPG/440px-Rufous_hornero_%28Red_ovenbird%29%28Furnarius_rufus%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rufous_hornero_(Red_ovenbird)(Furnarius_rufus).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The national animal of Argentina is the <a href="/wiki/Rufous_hornero" title="Rufous hornero">Rufous hornero</a>, a small songbird native to South America.</div></div></div>
<p>Argentina is one of the most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biodiverse" title="Biodiverse">biodiverse</a> countries in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbd_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-165">[155]</a></sup> hosting one of the greatest <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a> varieties in the world: 15 continental zones, 2 marine zones, and the Antarctic region are all represented in its territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbd_165-1"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-165">[155]</a></sup> This huge ecosystem variety has led to a biological diversity that is among the world's largest:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbd_165-2"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-165">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wcmc_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-wcmc-166">[156]</a></sup> 9,372 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">vascular plant</a> species (ranked 24th);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[G]</a></sup> 1,038 cataloged bird species (ranked 14th);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[H]</a></sup> 375 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammal</a> species (ranked 12th);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[I]</a></sup> 338 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptilian</a> species (ranked 16th); and 162 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibian</a> species (ranked 19th).
</p><p>The original pampa had virtually no trees; some imported species like the <a href="/wiki/Platanus_occidentalis" title="Platanus occidentalis">American sycamore</a> or <a href="/wiki/Eucalyptus" title="Eucalyptus">eucalyptus</a> are present along roads or in towns and country estates (<i>estancias</i>). The only tree-like plant native to the pampa is the evergreen <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Omb%C3%BA" title="Ombú">Ombú</a>. The surface soils of the pampa are a deep black color, primarily <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mollisols" title="Mollisols">mollisols</a>, known commonly as <i>humus</i>. This makes the region one of the most agriculturally productive on Earth; however, this is also responsible for decimating much of the original ecosystem, to make way for commercial agriculture. The western pampas receive less rainfall, this <i>dry pampa</i> is a plain of short grasses or <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Parks_of_Argentina" title="National Parks of Argentina">National Parks of Argentina</a> make up a network of 35 <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national parks</a> in Argentina. The parks cover a very varied set of terrains and <a href="/wiki/Biotope" title="Biotope">biotopes</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Barit%C3%BA_National_Park" title="Baritú National Park">Baritú National Park</a> on the northern border with <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> to <a href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego_National_Park" title="Tierra del Fuego National Park">Tierra del Fuego National Park</a> in the far south of the continent. The <a href="/wiki/Administraci%C3%B3n_de_Parques_Nacionales" title="Administración de Parques Nacionales">Administración de Parques Nacionales</a> (National Parks Administration) is the agency that preserves and manages these national parks along with <a href="/wiki/Natural_monument" title="Natural monument">Natural monuments</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Reserve" title="National Reserve">National Reserves</a> within the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[157]</a></sup> Argentina had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 7.21/10, ranking it 47th globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-171">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Argentina" title="Climate of Argentina">Climate of Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climatic_regions_of_Argentina" title="Climatic regions of Argentina">Climatic regions of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="423" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_ARG_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> in Argentina</div></div></div>
<p>In general, Argentina has four main climate types: warm, moderate, arid, and cold, all determined by the expanse across latitude, range in altitude, and relief features.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arggov_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-arggov-172">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[160]</a></sup> Although the most populated areas are generally <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate</a>, Argentina has an exceptional amount of climate diversity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FAO_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FAO-174">[161]</a></sup> ranging from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subtropical" title="Subtropical">subtropical</a> in the north to <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">polar</a> in the far south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[162]</a></sup> Consequently, there is a wide variety of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biomes" title="Biomes">biomes</a> in the country, including subtropical rain forests, semi-arid and <a href="/wiki/Arid" title="Arid">arid</a> regions, temperate plains in the Pampas, and cold subantarctic in the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fernandez_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fernandez-176">[163]</a></sup> The average annual precipitation ranges from 150 millimetres (6 in) in the driest parts of <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">Patagonia</a> to over 2,000 millimetres (79 in) in the westernmost parts of Patagonia and the northeastern parts of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FAO_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-FAO-174">[161]</a></sup> Mean annual temperatures range from 5 °C (41 °F) in the far south to 25 °C (77 °F) in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FAO_174-2"><a href="#cite_note-FAO-174">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>Major wind currents include the cool <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pampero_Winds" title="Pampero Winds">Pampero Winds</a> blowing on the flat plains of Patagonia and the Pampas; following the cold front, warm currents blow from the north in middle and late winter, creating mild conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069-177">[164]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Sudestada" title="Sudestada">Sudestada</a> usually moderates cold temperatures but brings very heavy rains, rough seas and <a href="/wiki/Coastal_flooding" title="Coastal flooding">coastal flooding</a>. It is most common in late autumn and winter along the central coast and in the Río de la Plata estuary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069-177">[164]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Zonda_wind" title="Zonda wind">Zonda</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Foehn_wind" title="Foehn wind">hot dry wind</a>, affects Cuyo and the central Pampas. Squeezed of all moisture during the 6,000 m (19,685 ft) descent from the Andes, Zonda winds can blow for hours with gusts up to 120 km/h (75 mph), fueling wildfires and causing damage; between June and November, when the Zonda blows, snowstorms and <a href="/wiki/Blizzard" title="Blizzard">blizzard</a> (<i>viento blanco</i>) conditions usually affect higher elevations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198053_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198053-178">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Argentina" title="Climate change in Argentina">Climate change in Argentina</a> is predicted to have significant effects on the living conditions in Argentina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cambioclimatico2009_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-cambioclimatico2009-179">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 30">: 30 </span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Argentina" title="Climate of Argentina">climate of Argentina</a> is changing with regards to precipitation patterns and temperatures. The highest increases in the precipitation (from the period 1960–2010) have occurred in the eastern parts of the country. The increase in precipitation has led to more variability in precipitation from year to year in the northern parts of the country, with a higher risk of prolonged <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Droughts" title="Droughts">droughts</a>, disfavoring agriculture in these <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions" title="Regions">regions</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg" title="Argentina features geographical locations such as this glacier, known as the Perito Moreno Glacier"><img alt="" data-file-height="3918" data-file-width="30000" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg/1000px-155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg/1500px-155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg/2000px-155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:155_-_Glacier_Perito_Moreno_-_Panorama_de_la_partie_nord_-_Janvier_2010.jpg" title="File:155 - Glacier Perito Moreno - Panorama de la partie nord - Janvier 2010.jpg"> </a></div>Argentina features geographical locations such as this glacier, known as the <a href="/wiki/Perito_Moreno_Glacier" title="Perito Moreno Glacier">Perito Moreno Glacier</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[167]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Argentina" title="Politics of Argentina">Politics of Argentina</a></div>
<p>In the 20th century, Argentina experienced significant political turmoil and democratic reversals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robinson_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson-181">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-182">[169]</a></sup> Between 1930 and 1976, the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Argentine_Republic" title="Armed Forces of the Argentine Republic">armed forces</a> overthrew six governments in Argentina;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_182-1"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-182">[169]</a></sup> and the country alternated periods of democracy (1912–1930, 1946–1955, and 1973–1976) with periods of restricted democracy and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_regime" title="Military regime">military rule</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robinson_181-1"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson-181">[168]</a></sup> Following a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transition_to_democracy" title="Transition to democracy">transition</a> that began in 1983,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anderson_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anderson-183">[170]</a></sup> full-scale democracy in Argentina was reestablished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robinson_181-2"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson-181">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_182-2"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-182">[169]</a></sup> Argentina's democracy endured through the <a href="/wiki/1998%E2%80%932002_Argentine_great_depression" title="1998–2002 Argentine great depression">2001–02 crisis</a> and to the present day; it is regarded as more robust than both its pre-1983 predecessors and other democracies in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_182-3"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-182">[169]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Argentina" title="Government of Argentina">Government of Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministries_of_the_Argentine_Republic" title="Ministries of the Argentine Republic">Ministries of the Argentine Republic</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Casa_Rosada,_Buenos_Aires,_Argentina.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2144" data-file-width="3694" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Casa_Rosada%2C_Buenos_Aires%2C_Argentina.jpg/220px-Casa_Rosada%2C_Buenos_Aires%2C_Argentina.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Casa_Rosada%2C_Buenos_Aires%2C_Argentina.jpg/330px-Casa_Rosada%2C_Buenos_Aires%2C_Argentina.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Casa_Rosada%2C_Buenos_Aires%2C_Argentina.jpg/440px-Casa_Rosada%2C_Buenos_Aires%2C_Argentina.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Casa_Rosada,_Buenos_Aires,_Argentina.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Casa_Rosada" title="Casa Rosada">Casa Rosada</a>, workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Argentina" title="President of Argentina">President</a></div></div></div>
<p>Argentina is a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> constitutional republic and <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._1_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._1-184">[171]</a></sup> The government is regulated by a system of <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">checks and balances</a> defined by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Argentina" title="Constitution of Argentina">Constitution of Argentina</a>, the country's supreme legal document. The <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_government" title="Seat of government">seat of government</a> is the city of <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, as designated by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_National_Congress" title="Argentine National Congress">Congress</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._3_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._3-185">[172]</a></sup> Suffrage is <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Equal_suffrage" title="Equal suffrage">equal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secret_ballot" title="Secret ballot">secret</a> and <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_voting" title="Compulsory voting">mandatory</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._37_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._37-186">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[J]</a></sup>
</p><p>The federal government is composed of three branches:
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_(6370115601).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_%286370115601%29.jpg/220px-Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_%286370115601%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_%286370115601%29.jpg/330px-Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_%286370115601%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_%286370115601%29.jpg/440px-Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_%286370115601%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palacio_del_Congreso_in_Buenos_Aires_(6370115601).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Argentina" title="National Congress of Argentina">National Congress</a> composed of the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Senate" title="Argentine Senate">Senate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Chamber_of_Deputies" title="Argentine Chamber of Deputies">Chamber of Deputies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._63_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._63-189">[175]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislative</a> branch consists of the <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> Congress, made up of the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Senate" title="Argentine Senate">Senate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Chamber_of_Deputies" title="Argentine Chamber of Deputies">Chamber of Deputies</a>. The Congress makes <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">declares war</a>, approves <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">treaties</a> and has the <a href="/wiki/Power_of_the_purse" title="Power of the purse">power of the purse</a> and of <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeachment</a>, by which it can remove sitting members of the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._53,_59,_75_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._53,_59,_75-190">[176]</a></sup> The Chamber of Deputies represents the people and has 257 voting members elected to a four-year term. Seats are apportioned among the provinces by population every tenth year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._45,_47,_50_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._45,_47,_50-191">[177]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> ten provinces have just five deputies while the <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires_Province" title="Buenos Aires Province">Buenos Aires Province</a>, being the most populous one, has 70. The Chamber of Senators represents the provinces, has 72 members elected <a href="/wiki/At-large" title="At-large">at-large</a> to six-year terms, with each province having three seats; one third of Senate seats are up for election every other year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._54,_56_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._54,_56-192">[178]</a></sup> At least one-third of the candidates presented by the parties must be women.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a> branch, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Argentina" title="President of Argentina">President</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military, can <a href="/wiki/Veto" title="Veto">veto</a> <a href="/wiki/Bill_(law)" title="Bill (law)">legislative bills</a> before they become law—subject to Congressional override—and appoints the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Argentina" title="Cabinet of Argentina">members of the Cabinet</a> and other officers, who administer and enforce federal laws and policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._99_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._99-193">[179]</a></sup> The President is elected <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct_vote" title="Direct vote">directly</a> by the vote of the people, serves a four-year term and may be elected to office no more than twice in a row.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._90_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._90-194">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judicial</a> branch includes the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Argentina" title="Supreme Court of Argentina">Supreme Court</a> and lower <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Argentina" title="Law of Argentina">federal courts</a> interpret laws and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_review" title="Judicial review">overturn those</a> they find <a href="/wiki/Constitutionality" title="Constitutionality">unconstitutional</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._116_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._116-195">[181]</a></sup> The Judicial is independent of the Executive and the Legislative. The Supreme Court has seven members appointed by the President—subject to Senate approval—who serve for life. The lower courts' judges are proposed by the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Magistracy_of_the_Nation" title="Council of Magistracy of the Nation">Council of Magistracy</a> (a secretariat composed of representatives of judges, lawyers, researchers, the Executive and the Legislative), and appointed by the president on Senate approval.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._99,_114_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._99,_114-196">[182]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Provinces">Provinces</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Argentina" title="Provinces of Argentina">Provinces of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><div class="noresize"><map name="ImageMap_3ed4a8d75f60dc7f"><area alt="Tierra del Fuego, Antarctica and South Atlantic Islands Province" coords="56,296,58,316,85,315,56,295" href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego_Province,_Argentina" shape="poly" title="Tierra del Fuego, Antarctica and South Atlantic Islands Province"/><area alt="Santa alt="Río Negro" coords="27,197,25,190,49,169,49,154,52,156,52,158,55,159,56,158,62,164,72,165,85,168,85,182,89,185,85,187,74,183,72,185,74,193" href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Negro_Province" shape="poly" Pampa" coords="48,152,51,153,55,157,64,165,73,164,86,168,86,129,71,129,71,138,48,139" href="/wiki/La_Pampa_Province" shape="poly" title="La Pampa"/><area alt="Buenos Aires Province" Province"/><area alt="Buenos Aires City" coords="120,124,123,127" href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" shape="rect" title="Buenos Aires City"/><area alt="Santa Fe" coords="89,123,99,123,106,115,109,114,105,107,107,98,116,87,116,75,120,71,121,65,122,64,99,63,95,85,98,89,95,99,95,101,99,110" href="/wiki/Santa_Fe_Province" shape="poly" title="Santa Fe"/><area alt="Córdoba" coords="71,129,86,128,86,123,89,123,98,110,95,103,95,98,98,90,94,85,91,85,91,82,89,80,80,78,74,78,71,79,73,80,70,83,65,92,66,100,72,104" href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba_Province,_Argentina" href="/wiki/La_Rioja_Province,_Argentina" shape="poly" title="La Rioja"/><area alt="Catamarca" href="/wiki/Catamarca_Province" shape="poly" title="Catamarca"/><area alt="Salta" coords="41,36,46,39,50,38,58,38,58,41,56,43,59,48,62,47,65,48,66,46,69,46,75,48,77,42,85,42,94,30,94,13,89,7,85,7,83,9,81,7,78,8,79,11,76,13,74,10,72,8,70,8,68,13,70,17,71,20,72,21,76,21,77,21,78,27,76,28,76,31,73,31,66,30,63,27,62,23,60,21,59,22,59,28,57,29,54,26,52,24,42,31,40,35" href="/wiki/Salta_Province" shape="poly" title="Salta"/><area alt="Jujuy" coords="51,25,53,24,56,27,59,28,60,24,59,21,60,20,62,22,63,25,64,27,66,30,68,30,73,31,74,30,75,31,76,27,78,27,78,20,76,21,71,21,70,18,67,14,69,8,65,8,63,7,60,4,59,7,57,10,55,12,53,12,51,15,53,18" href="/wiki/Jujuy_Province" shape="poly" title="Jujuy"/><area alt="Tucumán" coords="63,47,65,49,67,47,66,46,66,45,68,46,71,47,75,48,77,50,71,58,72,62,70,64,69,62,67,63,64,62,64,57,62,57,64,52,62,50" href="/wiki/Tucum%C3%A1n_Province" shape="poly" title="Tucumán"/><area alt="Santiago del Estero" coords="77,43,78,41,80,42,84,42,86,41,99,42,100,63,95,84,91,85,91,82,90,80,84,81,82,78,80,78,73,78,74,76,72,75,72,70,70,69,70,66,70,63,72,62,72,59,77,51,76,48" href="/wiki/Santiago_del_Estero_Province" shape="poly" title="Santiago del Estero"/><area alt="Chaco" coords="84,42,100,42,99,64,122,64,122,57,128,54,122,48,119,49,110,38,98,31,98,29,94,28,94,31" href="/wiki/Chaco_Province" shape="poly" title="Chaco"/><area alt="Formosa" coords="94,27,99,31,109,35,119,48,122,48,128,54,129,49,134,42,137,41,132,36,130,35,126,34,125,34,117,30,115,27,110,24,107,25,94,13" href="/wiki/Formosa_Province" shape="poly" title="Formosa"/><area alt="Corrientes" coords="115,87,121,84,123,84,124,83,127,85,129,90,130,86,135,83,134,82,136,78,138,79,142,76,144,74,147,70,149,67,147,62,148,58,144,60,143,60,141,60,130,56,126,56,123,59,123,62,121,66,120,71,116,76" href="/wiki/Corrientes_Province" shape="poly" title="Corrientes"/><area alt="Misiones" coords="148,58,146,62,149,67,151,66,155,63,158,64,162,60,165,58,168,52,167,49,167,47,165,42,162,42,160,42,159,44,158,51,156,54,150,58" href="/wiki/Misiones_Province" shape="poly" title="Misiones"/><area alt="Entre Ríos" coords="107,98,112,93,115,87,121,84,123,84,127,85,128,87,129,89,131,91,131,94,129,97,128,99,127,100,127,102,126,106,126,112,123,113,123,120,110,116,106,110,106,109,105,105,107,99" href="/wiki/Provincia_de_Entre_R%C3%ADos" shape="poly" title="Entre Ríos"/><area alt="Malvinas Islands" coords="91,274,125,297" href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" shape="rect" title="Malvinas Islands"/><area alt="Argentine Antarctica" coords="162,327,132,264,150,257,164,256,174,258,191,264" href="/wiki/Argentine_Antarctica" shape="poly" title="Argentine Antarctica"/></map><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="936" data-file-width="566" decoding="async" height="331" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Map_of_Argentina_with_provinces_names_en.png/200px-Map_of_Argentina_with_provinces_names_en.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Map_of_Argentina_with_provinces_names_en.png/300px-Map_of_Argentina_with_provinces_names_en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Map_of_Argentina_with_provinces_names_en.png/400px-Map_of_Argentina_with_provinces_names_en.png 2x" usemap="#ImageMap_3ed4a8d75f60dc7f" width="200"/></div> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Argentina_with_provinces_names_en.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Provinces of Argentina. Click to explore.</div></div></div>
<p>Argentina is a federation of twenty-three provinces and one <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_city" title="Autonomous city">autonomous city</a>, Buenos Aires. Provinces are divided for administration purposes into <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Argentina" title="Departments of Argentina">departments</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Argentina" title="Municipalities of Argentina">municipalities</a>, except for Buenos Aires Province, which is divided into <a href="/wiki/Partidos_of_Buenos_Aires" title="Partidos of Buenos Aires">partidos</a>. The City of Buenos Aires is divided into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barrios_and_Communes_of_Buenos_Aires" title="Barrios and Communes of Buenos Aires">communes</a>.
</p><p>Provinces hold all the power that they chose not to delegate to the federal government;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._121_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._121-197">[183]</a></sup> they must be representative republics and must not contradict the Constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._5–6_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._5–6-198">[184]</a></sup> Beyond this they are fully autonomous: they enact their own constitutions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._123_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._123-199">[185]</a></sup> freely organize their local governments,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._122_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._122-200">[186]</a></sup> and own and manage their natural and financial resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._124–125_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._124–125-201">[187]</a></sup> Some provinces have bicameral legislatures, while others have <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[K]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the War of Independence the main cities and their surrounding countrysides became provinces though the intervention of their <a href="/wiki/Cabildo_(council)" title="Cabildo (council)">cabildos</a>. The Anarchy of the Year XX completed this process, shaping the original thirteen provinces. Jujuy seceded from <a href="/wiki/Salta_Province" title="Salta Province">Salta</a> in 1834, and the thirteen provinces became fourteen.
After seceding for a decade, Buenos Aires accepted the 1853 Constitution of Argentina in 1861, and was made a federal territory in 1880.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519-204">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>An 1862 law designated as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_territory" title="National territory">national territories</a> those under federal control but outside the frontiers of the provinces. In 1884 they served as bases for the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Governorate" title="Governorate">governorates</a> of Misiones, Formosa, Chaco, La Pampa, Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERock1987155_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERock1987155-205">[190]</a></sup>
The agreement about a frontier dispute with Chile in 1900 created the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=National_Territory_of_Los_Andes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="National Territory of Los Andes (page does not exist)">National Territory of Los Andes</a>; its lands were incorporated into Jujuy, Salta and <a href="/wiki/Catamarca_Province" title="Catamarca Province">Catamarca</a> in 1943.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519_204-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519-204">[189]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/La_Pampa_Province" title="La Pampa Province">La Pampa</a> and Chaco became provinces in 1951. Misiones did so in 1953, and <a href="/wiki/Formosa_Province" title="Formosa Province">Formosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neuqu%C3%A9n_Province" title="Neuquén Province">Neuquén</a>, <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Negro_Province" title="Río Negro Province">Río Negro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chubut_Province" title="Chubut Province">Chubut</a> and Santa Cruz, in 1955. The last national territory, Tierra del Fuego, became the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego,_Ant%C3%A1rtida_e_Islas_del_Atl%C3%A1ntico_Sur_Province" title="Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province">Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province</a> in 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519_204-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519-204">[189]</a></sup> It has three components, although two are nominal because they are not under Argentine sovereignty. The first is the Argentine part of Tierra del Fuego; the second is an area of Antarctica claimed by Argentina that overlaps with similar areas claimed by the UK and Chile; the third comprises the two disputed British Overseas Territories of the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Duggan_and_Lewis_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-Duggan_and_Lewis-206">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Argentina" title="Foreign relations of Argentina">Foreign relations of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:G20_Argentina_2018.jpg"><img alt="Presidents all standing together." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2114" data-file-width="4459" decoding="async" height="104" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/G20_Argentina_2018.jpg/220px-G20_Argentina_2018.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/G20_Argentina_2018.jpg/330px-G20_Argentina_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/G20_Argentina_2018.jpg/440px-G20_Argentina_2018.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:G20_Argentina_2018.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G 20</a> leaders gathered in Argentina for the <a href="/wiki/2018_G20_Buenos_Aires_summit" title="2018 G20 Buenos Aires summit">2018 G20 Buenos Aires summit</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="1425" decoding="async" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png/220px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png/330px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png/440px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina" title="List of diplomatic missions of Argentina">Diplomatic missions of Argentina</a></div></div></div>
<p>Foreign policy is handled by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs,_International_Trade_and_Worship" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International Trade and Worship">Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International Trade and Worship</a>, which answers to the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Argentina" title="President of Argentina">President</a>. The country is one of the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_15" title="Group of 15">G-15</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a> of the world, and a founding member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN" title="UN">UN</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">WBG</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> and <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">OAS</a>.
In 2012 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_election,_2012" title="United Nations Security Council election, 2012">Argentina was elected again</a> to a two-year non-permanent position on the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> and is participating in major peacekeeping operations in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Stabilization_Mission_in_Haiti" title="United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Peacekeeping_Force_in_Cyprus" title="United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">Western Sahara</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[192]</a></sup> Argentina is described as a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWood198818Solomon19973_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWood198818Solomon19973-36">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cooper_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cooper-208">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>A prominent Latin American<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuntington20006Nierop200161Lake200955Papadopoulos2010283Malamud20119Boughton2012101_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuntington20006Nierop200161Lake200955Papadopoulos2010283Malamud20119Boughton2012101-37">[31]</a></sup> and Southern Cone<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris198863AdlerGreve200978Ruiz-DanaGoldschagClaroBlanco200918_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris198863AdlerGreve200978Ruiz-DanaGoldschagClaroBlanco200918-38">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a>, Argentina co-founded <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">OEI</a> and <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Latin_American_and_Caribbean_States" title="Community of Latin American and Caribbean States">CELAC</a>.
It is also a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosur</a> block, having Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay and <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> as partners. Since 2002 the country has emphasized its key role in <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_integration" title="Latin American integration">Latin American integration</a>, and the block—which has some supranational legislative functions—is its first international priority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011600vol._II_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011600vol._II-209">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina claims 965,597 km<sup>2</sup> (372,819 sq mi) in <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Antarctica" title="Argentine Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, where it has the world's oldest <a href="/wiki/Orcadas_Base" title="Orcadas Base">continuous state presence</a>, since 1904.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[195]</a></sup> This overlaps claims by <a href="/wiki/Chilean_Antarctic_Territory" title="Chilean Antarctic Territory">Chile</a> and the <a href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" title="British Antarctic Territory">United Kingdom</a>, though all such claims fall under the provisions of the 1961 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty" title="Antarctic Treaty">Antarctic Treaty</a>, of which Argentina is a founding signatory and permanent consulting member, with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_Secretariat" title="Antarctic Treaty Secretariat">Antarctic Treaty Secretariat</a> being based in Buenos Aires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" title="Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute">disputes sovereignty</a> over the Falkland Islands (Spanish: <i lang="es">Islas Malvinas</i>), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_South_Sandwich_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" title="South Georgia and South Sandwich Islands sovereignty dispute">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_ArgentinaT._P._1_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_ArgentinaT._P._1-212">[197]</a></sup> which are administered by the United Kingdom as <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">Overseas Territories</a>. Argentina is a party to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rome_Statute_of_the_International_Criminal_Court" title="Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court">Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[198]</a></sup> Argentina is a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">Major non-NATO ally</a> since 1998 <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Major_Non-NATO_Ally_Status_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-Major_Non-NATO_Ally_Status-39">[33]</a></sup> and an <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> candidate country since January 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[199]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Armed_forces">Armed forces</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Argentine_Republic" title="Armed Forces of the Argentine Republic">Armed Forces of the Argentine Republic</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1069" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg/220px-Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg/330px-Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg/440px-Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Argentina_Air_Force_McDonnell_Douglas_A-4AR_Fightinghawk_Lofting-3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin_A-4AR_Fightinghawk" title="Lockheed Martin A-4AR Fightinghawk">Lockheed Martin A-4AR Fightinghawk</a> operated by the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Air_Force" title="Argentine Air Force">Argentine Air Force</a></div></div></div>
<p>The president holds the title of commander-in-chief of the Argentine Armed Forces, as part of a legal framework that imposes a strict separation between national defense and internal security systems:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lsi_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-216">[201]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_defense_industry" title="Argentine defense industry">National Defense System</a>, an exclusive responsibility of the federal government,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._125–126_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._125–126-217">[202]</a></sup> coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Argentina)" title="Ministry of Defense (Argentina)">Ministry of Defense</a>, and comprising the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Army" title="Argentine Army">Army</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Navy" title="Argentine Navy">Navy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Air_Force" title="Argentine Air Force">Air Force</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[203]</a></sup> Ruled and monitored by Congress<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._21,_75,_99_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._21,_75,_99-219">[204]</a></sup> through the Houses' Defense Committees,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-resdal_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-resdal-220">[205]</a></sup> it is organized on the essential principle of legitimate self-defense: the repelling of any external military aggression in order to guarantee freedom of the people, national sovereignty, and territorial integrity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-resdal_220-1"><a href="#cite_note-resdal-220">[205]</a></sup> Its secondary missions include committing to multinational operations within the framework of the United Nations, participating in internal support missions, assisting friendly countries, and establishing a sub-regional defense system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-resdal_220-2"><a href="#cite_note-resdal-220">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Military_service" title="Military service">Military service</a> is voluntary, with enlistment age between 18 and 24 years old and no <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[206]</a></sup> Argentina's defense has historically been one of the best equipped in the region, even managing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_defense_industry" title="Argentine defense industry">its own weapon research facilities, shipyards, ordnance, tank and plane factories</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaldifassiAbetti199465–86_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaldifassiAbetti199465–86-222">[207]</a></sup> However, real military expenditures declined steadily after the defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Falklands_War" title="Falklands War">Falklands/Malvinas War</a> and the defense budget in 2011 was only about 0.74% of GDP, a historical minimum,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[208]</a></sup> below the Latin American average. Within the defence budget itself funding for training and even basic maintenance has been significantly cut, a factor contributing to the <a href="/wiki/Disappearance_of_ARA_San_Juan" title="Disappearance of ARA San Juan">accidental loss of the Argentine submarine San Juan</a> in 2017. With the United Kingdom also actively acting to restrict even modest Argentinian military modernization efforts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[209]</a></sup> the result has been a steady erosion of Argentine military capabilities, with some arguing that Argentina had, by the end of the 2010s, ceased to be a capable military power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[210]</a></sup>
</p>
