<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1108" data-file-width="898" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Argentine destroyer <a href="/wiki/ARA_Almirante_Brown_(D-10)" title="ARA Almirante Brown (D-10)">ARA <i>Almirante Brown</i> (D-10)</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARA_Almirante_Brown_(D-10)_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-ARA_Almirante_Brown_(D-10)-226">[211]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Interior_Security_System" title="Argentine Interior Security System">Interior Security System</a>, jointly administered by the federal and subscribing provincial governments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lsi_216-1"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-216">[201]</a></sup> At the federal level it is coordinated by the Interior, <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Argentina)" title="Ministry of Defense (Argentina)">Security</a> and Justice ministries, and monitored by Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lsi_216-2"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-216">[201]</a></sup> It is enforced by the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Federal_Police" title="Argentine Federal Police">Federal Police</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Naval_Prefecture" title="Argentine Naval Prefecture">Prefecture</a>, which fulfills <a href="/wiki/Coast_guard" title="Coast guard">coast guard</a> duties; the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_National_Gendarmerie" title="Argentine National Gendarmerie">Gendarmerie</a>, which serves <a href="/wiki/Border_guard" title="Border guard">border guard</a> tasks; and the <a href="/wiki/Airport_Security_Police_(Argentina)" title="Airport Security Police (Argentina)">Airport Security Police</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[212]</a></sup> At the provincial level it is coordinated by the respective internal security ministries and enforced by local police agencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lsi_216-3"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-216">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina was the only South American country to send warships and cargo planes in 1991 to the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> under <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">UN</a> mandate and has remained involved in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> efforts in multiple locations like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNPROFOR" title="UNPROFOR">UNPROFOR</a> in <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a>/<a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Fonseca" title="Gulf of Fonseca">Gulf of Fonseca</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Peacekeeping_Force_in_Cyprus" title="United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus">UNFICYP</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> (where among Army and Marines troops the Air Force provided the UN Air contingent since 1994) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MINUSTAH" title="MINUSTAH">MINUSTAH</a> in <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>. Argentina is the only Latin American country to maintain troops in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> during <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SFOR" title="SFOR">SFOR</a> (and later <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EUFOR" title="EUFOR">EUFOR</a>) operations where <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Combat_engineering" title="Combat engineering">combat engineers</a> of the Argentine Armed Forces are embedded in an <a href="/wiki/Italian_Army" title="Italian Army">Italian brigade</a>.
</p><p>In 2007, an Argentine contingent including helicopters, boats and water purification plants was sent to help <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> against their worst floods in decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[213]</a></sup> In 2010 the Armed Forces were also involved in <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_response_by_national_governments_to_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="Humanitarian response by national governments to the 2010 Haiti earthquake">Haiti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_response_to_the_2010_Chile_earthquake" title="Humanitarian response to the 2010 Chile earthquake">Chile</a> humanitarian responses after their respective earthquakes.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Argentina" title="Economy of Argentina">Economy of Argentina</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_foreign_trade" title="Argentine foreign trade">Argentine foreign trade</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Argentina_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Argentina_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/220px-Argentina_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Argentina_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/330px-Argentina_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Argentina_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/440px-Argentina_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Argentina_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Argentina exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p>Benefiting from rich <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_resources" title="Natural resources">natural resources</a>, a highly literate population, a diversified industrial base, and an export-oriented agricultural sector, the economy of Argentina is Latin America's third-largest,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsj1_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-wsj1-229">[214]</a></sup> and the second largest in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[215]</a></sup> It has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">"very high"</a> rating on the Human Development Index<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNHDR_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-UNHDR-20">[15]</a></sup> and a relatively <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">high GDP per capita</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-231">[216]</a></sup> with a considerable <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_market" title="Internal market">internal market</a> size and a growing share of the high-tech sector.
</p><p>Access to <a href="/wiki/Biocapacity" title="Biocapacity">biocapacity</a> in Argentina is much higher than world average. In 2016, Argentina had 6.8 global hectares<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-footprintdata_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-232">[217]</a></sup> of biocapacity per person within its territory, much more than the world average of 1.6 global hectares per person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[218]</a></sup> In 2016 Argentina used 3.4 global hectares of biocapacity per person – their <a href="/wiki/Ecological_footprint" title="Ecological footprint">ecological footprint</a> of consumption. This means they use half as much biocapacity as Argentina contains. As a result, Argentina is running a biocapacity reserve.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-footprintdata_232-1"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-232">[217]</a></sup> A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emerging_economy" title="Emerging economy">middle emerging economy</a> and one of the world's top developing nations, is a member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-undp2013_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-undp2013-234">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[L]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, however, its economic performance has been very uneven, with high economic growth alternating with severe recessions, income maldistribution and—in the recent decades—increasing poverty. Early in the 20th century Argentina achieved development,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701_30-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701-30">[24]</a></sup> and became the world's seventh richest country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_29-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-29">[23]</a></sup> Although managing to keep a place among the top fifteen economies until mid-century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_29-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-29">[23]</a></sup> it suffered a long and steady decline, but it is still a high income country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[220]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Microcentro,_Buenos_Aires_(40774240522).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3688" data-file-width="3565" decoding="async" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg/220px-Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg/330px-Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg/440px-Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Microcentro,_Buenos_Aires_(40774240522).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Catalinas_Norte" title="Catalinas Norte">Catalinas Norte</a> is an important business complex composed of nineteen commercial office buildings and occupied by numerous leading Argentine companies.</div></div></div>
<p>High <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a>—a weakness of the Argentine economy for decades—has become a trouble once again,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-2011-02-06_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-2011-02-06-237">[221]</a></sup> with an annual rate of 24.8% in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Official_INDEC_consumer_price_index_figures_(Spanish)_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Official_INDEC_consumer_price_index_figures_(Spanish)-238">[222]</a></sup> To deter it and support the peso, the government imposed foreign currency control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[223]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Income_distribution" title="Income distribution">Income distribution</a>, having improved since 2002, is classified as "medium", although it is still considerably unequal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gini_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-gini-18">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina ranks 85th out of 180 countries in the <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s 2017 <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[224]</a></sup> an improvement of 22 positions over its 2014 rankings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[225]</a></sup> Argentina settled its long-standing debt default crisis in 2016 with the so-called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vulture_funds" title="Vulture funds">vulture funds</a> after the election of Mauricio Macri, allowing Argentina to enter capital markets for the first time in a decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>The government of Argentina defaulted on 22 May 2020 by failing to pay a $500 million due date to its creditors. Negotiations for the restructuring of $66 billion of its debt continue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2022, the President of Argentina, Alberto Fernandez, requested the formal accession of his country to the <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a> group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[229]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture_and_livestock">Agriculture and livestock</span></h3>
<p>Argentina is the largest producer in the world of <a href="/wiki/Yerba_mate" title="Yerba mate">yerba mate</a> (due to the large domestic consumption of <a href="/wiki/Mate_(drink)" title="Mate (drink)">mate</a>), one of the 5 largest producers in the world of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soybeans" title="Soybeans">soybeans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_seed" title="Sunflower seed">sunflower seed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lemon" title="Lemon">lemon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pear" title="Pear">pear</a>, one of the 10 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">grape</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artichoke" title="Artichoke">artichoke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a>, and one of the 15 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sorghum" title="Sorghum">sorghum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Grapefruit" title="Grapefruit">grapefruit</a>. Argentina has been a major producer of wheat since before 1900. However, with the worldwide rise in the importance of soy, it has become the dominant crop in the country. Currently, only Brazil and USA produce more soy than Argentina, and only USA, China and Brazil produce more maize. It's the largest producer in South America of wheat, sunflower seed, barley, lemon and pear.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[231]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Wine" title="Wine">wine</a>, Argentina is usually among the 10 largest producers in the world. In 2018 it was in 5th place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina is also a traditional meat exporter, having been, in 2019, the 4th world producer of <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>, with a production of 3 million tons (only behind USA, Brazil and China), the 4th world producer of <a href="/wiki/Honey" title="Honey">honey</a>, and the 10th world producer of <a href="/wiki/Wool" title="Wool">wool</a>, in addition to other relevant productions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[234]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_Resources">Natural Resources</span></h3>
<p>The metallic mineral production of Argentina is not as relevant as that of other countries. It stands out for being the 4th largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[235]</a></sup> 9th of <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[236]</a></sup> and 17th of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[237]</a></sup> worldwide (2019 data). The country stands out in the production of <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>, being the largest producer in South America and the 18th largest in the world, and has an average annual production close to 500 thousand barrels/day of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a>, even with the under-utilization of the Vaca Muerta field, due to the country's technical and financial inability to extract these resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[239]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry">Industry</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Argentina" title="Industry in Argentina">Industry in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="439" data-file-width="759" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg/220px-Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg/330px-Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg/440px-Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fiat-C%C3%B3rdoba.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fiat" title="Fiat">Fiat</a> factory in <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Argentina" title="Córdoba, Argentina">Córdoba, Argentina</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> lists the top producing countries each year, based on the total value of production. According to the 2019 list, Argentina has the 31st most valuable industry in the world (U$57.7 billion).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[240]</a></sup> This year, the country was the 31st world producer of <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, the 28th producer of <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry" title="Automotive industry">vehicles</a>, the 22nd world producer of <a href="/wiki/Beer" title="Beer">beer</a>, the 4th world producer of <a href="/wiki/Soybean_oil" title="Soybean oil">soybean oil</a> and the 3rd world producer of <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_oil" title="Sunflower oil">sunflower oil</a>, among other products.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">manufacturing</a> accounted for 20.3% of GDP—the largest sector in the nation's economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoeco1_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-261">[245]</a></sup> Well-integrated into Argentine agriculture, half of the industrial exports have rural origin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoeco1_261-1"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-261">[245]</a></sup> With a 6.5% production growth rate in 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[246]</a></sup> the diversified manufacturing sector rests on a steadily growing network of <a href="/wiki/Industrial_park" title="Industrial park">industrial parks</a> (314 as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[248]</a></sup> In 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the leading sectors by volume were: food processing, beverages and tobacco products; motor vehicles and auto parts; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Textiles" title="Textiles">textiles</a> and leather; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Petroleum_refineries" title="Petroleum refineries">refinery products</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biodiesel" title="Biodiesel">biodiesel</a>; chemicals and pharmaceuticals; steel, aluminum and iron; industrial and farm machinery; home appliances and furniture; plastics and tires; glass and cement; and recording and print media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoeco1_261-2"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-261">[245]</a></sup> In addition, Argentina has since long been one of the top five wine-producing countries in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoeco1_261-3"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-261">[245]</a></sup> However, it has also been classified as one of the 74 countries where instances of <a href="/wiki/Child_labour" title="Child labour">child labour</a> and <a href="/wiki/Forced_labour" title="Forced labour">forced labour</a> have been observed and mentioned in a 2014 report published by the <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_International_Labor_Affairs" title="Bureau of International Labor Affairs">Bureau of International Labor Affairs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ilab_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-ilab-265">[249]</a></sup> The ILAB's <i><a href="/wiki/List_of_Goods_Produced_by_Child_Labor_or_Forced_Labor" title="List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor">List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor</a></i> shows that many of the goods produced by child labour or forced labour comes from the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Argentina" title="Agriculture in Argentina">agricultural sector</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ilab_265-1"><a href="#cite_note-ilab-265">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>Córdoba is Argentina's major industrial centre, hosting metalworking, motor vehicle and auto parts manufactures. Next in importance are the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Buenos_Aires" title="Greater Buenos Aires">Greater Buenos Aires</a> area (food processing, metallurgy, motor vehicles and auto parts, chemicals and petrochemicals, consumer durables, textiles and printing); <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rosario" title="Rosario">Rosario</a> (food processing, metallurgy, farm machinery, oil refining, chemicals, and tanning); San Miguel de Tucumán (sugar refining); <a href="/wiki/San_Lorenzo,_Santa_Fe" title="San Lorenzo, Santa Fe">San Lorenzo</a> (chemicals and pharmaceuticals); <a href="/wiki/San_Nicol%C3%A1s_de_los_Arroyos" title="San Nicolás de los Arroyos">San Nicolás de los Arroyos</a> (steel milling and metallurgy); and <a href="/wiki/Ushuaia" title="Ushuaia">Ushuaia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%ADa_Blanca" title="Bahía Blanca">Bahía Blanca</a> (oil refining).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn2_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-eotn2-266">[250]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (April 2018)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>]</sup>
Other manufacturing enterprises are located in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe_Province" title="Santa Fe Province">Santa Fe</a> (zinc and copper smelting, and flour milling); Mendoza and Neuquén (wineries and fruit processing); Chaco (textiles and sawmills); and Santa Cruz, Salta and Chubut (oil refining).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn2_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-eotn2-266">[250]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (April 2018)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>]</sup> The electric output of Argentina in 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> totaled over 122 <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt-hour" title="Kilowatt-hour">TWh</a> (440 <a href="/wiki/Joule" title="Joule">PJ</a>), of which about 37% was consumed by industrial activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[251]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Argentina" title="Tourism in Argentina">Tourism in Argentina</a></div>
<p>The country had 5.57 million visitors in 2013, ranking in terms of the international tourist arrivals as the top destination in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, and second in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> after Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNWTO2014_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2014-268">[252]</a></sup> Revenues from international tourists reached <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$4.41</span> billion in 2013, down from <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$4.89</span> billion in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNWTO2014_268-1"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2014-268">[252]</a></sup> The country's capital city, <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, is the most visited city in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[253]</a></sup> There are 30 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Parks_of_Argentina" title="National Parks of Argentina">National Parks of Argentina</a> including many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Argentina" title="World Heritage Sites in Argentina">World Heritage Sites</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1508px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Panorama of the Bariloche region and Lake Nahuel Huapi from Cerro Campanario"><img alt="" data-file-height="1833" data-file-width="17745" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg/1500px-Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg/2250px-Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg/3000px-Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="1500"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Panorama_from_Cerro_Campanario_-_Bariloche_-_panoramio.jpg" title="File:Panorama from Cerro Campanario - Bariloche - panoramio.jpg"> </a></div>Panorama of the <a href="/wiki/Bariloche" title="Bariloche">Bariloche</a> region and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lake_Nahuel_Huapi" title="Lake Nahuel Huapi">Lake Nahuel Huapi</a> from Cerro Campanario</div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transports">Transports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Argentina" title="Transport in Argentina">Transport in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2143" data-file-width="1327" decoding="async" height="355" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg/220px-Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg/330px-Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg/440px-Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Carreteras_Duplas_de_Argentina_2020.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Duplicate Highways of Argentina, in red</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2134" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG/220px-Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG/330px-Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG/440px-Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Autopista_Rosario_-_C%C3%B3rdoba_km_365_hacia_el_Este.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rosario-C%C3%B3rdoba_Highway" title="Rosario-Córdoba Highway">Rosario-Córdoba Highway</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg/220px-Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg/330px-Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg/440px-Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Train_in_Argentina_at_Sunset.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Passenger train near <a href="/wiki/Mar_del_Plata" title="Mar del Plata">Mar del Plata</a></div></div></div>
<p>By 2004<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Buenos Aires, all provincial capitals except Ushuaia, and all medium-sized towns were interconnected by 69,412 km (43,131 mi) of paved roads, out of a total road network of 231,374 km (143,769 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[254]</a></sup> In 2021, the country had about 2,800 km (1,740 mi) of <a href="/wiki/Dual_carriageway" title="Dual carriageway">duplicated highways</a>, most leaving the capital <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, linking it with cities like <a href="/wiki/Rosario,_Santa_Fe" title="Rosario, Santa Fe">Rosario</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba_(Argentina)" title="Córdoba (Argentina)">Córdoba</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Fe_(Argentina)" title="Santa Fe (Argentina)">Santa Fe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mar_del_Plata" title="Mar del Plata">Mar del Plata</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paso_de_los_Libres" title="Paso de los Libres">Paso de los Libres</a> (in border with Brazil), there are also duplicated highways leaving from <a href="/wiki/Mendoza,_Argentina" title="Mendoza, Argentina">Mendoza</a> towards the capital, and between Córdoba and Santa Fé, among other locations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[255]</a></sup> Nevertheless, this road infrastructure is still inadequate and cannot handle the sharply growing demand caused by deterioration of the railway system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn1_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-272">[256]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina has the largest <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Argentina" title="Rail transport in Argentina">railway system</a> in Latin America, with 36,966 km (22,970 mi) of operating lines in 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, out of a full network of almost 48,000 km (29,826 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[257]</a></sup> This system links all 23 provinces plus Buenos Aires City, and connects with all neighbouring countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn1_272-1"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-272">[256]</a></sup> There are four incompatible <a href="/wiki/Track_gauge" title="Track gauge">gauges</a> in use; this forces virtually all interregional freight traffic to pass through Buenos Aires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn1_272-2"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-272">[256]</a></sup> The system has been in decline since the 1940s: regularly running up large budgetary deficits, by 1991 it was transporting 1,400 times less goods than it did in 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn1_272-3"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-272">[256]</a></sup> However, in recent years the system has experienced a <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Argentina#Recent_developments_and_moves_towards_re-nationalisation" title="Rail transport in Argentina">greater degree of investment</a> from the state, in both commuter rail lines and long-distance lines, renewing rolling stock and infrastructure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[259]</a></sup> In April 2015, by overwhelming majority the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Senate" title="Argentine Senate">Argentine Senate</a> passed a law which re-created <a href="/wiki/Ferrocarriles_Argentinos" title="Ferrocarriles Argentinos">Ferrocarriles Argentinos</a> (2015), effectively re-nationalising the country's railways, a move which saw support from all major political parties on both sides of the political spectrum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were about 11,000 km (6,835 mi) of <a href="/wiki/Waterway" title="Waterway">waterways</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[263]</a></sup> mostly comprising the La Plata, Paraná, Paraguay and Uruguay rivers, with Buenos Aires, <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%A1rate,_Buenos_Aires" title="Zárate, Buenos Aires">Zárate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Campana,_Buenos_Aires" title="Campana, Buenos Aires">Campana</a>, Rosario, San Lorenzo, Santa Fe, <a href="/wiki/Barranqueras" title="Barranqueras">Barranqueras</a> and San Nicolas de los Arroyos as the main <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fluvial_port" title="Fluvial port">fluvial ports</a>.
Some of the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sea_port" title="Sea port">sea ports</a> are <a href="/wiki/La_Plata" title="La Plata">La Plata</a>–<a href="/wiki/Ensenada,_Buenos_Aires" title="Ensenada, Buenos Aires">Ensenada</a>, Bahía Blanca, <a href="/wiki/Mar_del_Plata" title="Mar del Plata">Mar del Plata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quequ%C3%A9n" title="Quequén">Quequén</a>–<a href="/wiki/Necochea" title="Necochea">Necochea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Comodoro_Rivadavia" title="Comodoro Rivadavia">Comodoro Rivadavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Deseado" title="Puerto Deseado">Puerto Deseado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Madryn" title="Puerto Madryn">Puerto Madryn</a>, Ushuaia and <a href="/wiki/San_Antonio_Oeste" title="San Antonio Oeste">San Antonio Oeste</a>.
Buenos Aires has historically been the most important port; however since the 1990s the Up-River port region has become dominant: stretching along 67 km (42 mi) of the Paraná river shore in Santa Fe province, it includes 17 ports and in 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> accounted for 50% of all exports.
</p><p>In 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were 161 airports with paved runways<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[264]</a></sup> out of more than a thousand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn1_272-4"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-272">[256]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ezeiza_International_Airport" title="Ezeiza International Airport">Ezeiza International Airport</a>, about 35 km (22 mi) from downtown Buenos Aires,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200076_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200076-281">[265]</a></sup> is the largest in the country, followed by <a href="/wiki/Cataratas_del_Iguaz%C3%BA_International_Airport" title="Cataratas del Iguazú International Airport">Cataratas del Iguazú</a> in Misiones, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Plumerillo_International_Airport" title="El Plumerillo International Airport">El Plumerillo</a> in Mendoza.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eotn1_272-5"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-272">[256]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aeroparque" title="Aeroparque">Aeroparque</a>, in the city of Buenos Aires, is the most important domestic airport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200024–25_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200024–25-282">[266]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Argentina" title="Electricity sector in Argentina">Electricity sector in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="574" data-file-width="604" decoding="async" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg/220px-Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg/330px-Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg/440px-Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atucha_I_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Atucha I Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha Nuclear Power Plant</a> was the first nuclear power plant in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[267]</a></sup> The electricity comes from 3 operational <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactors</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Embalse_Nuclear_Power_Station" title="Embalse Nuclear Power Station">Embalse Nuclear Power Station</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atucha_I_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Atucha I Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha I</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atucha_II_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Atucha II Nuclear Power Plant">II</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2020, more than 60% of Argentina's electricity came from non-renewable sources such as natural gas, oil and coal. 27% came from hydropower, 7.3% from wind and solar energy and 4.4% from nuclear energy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[268]</a></sup> At the end of 2021 Argentina was the 21st country in the world in terms of installed hydroelectric power (11.3 GW), the 26th country in the world in terms of installed wind energy (3.2 GW) and the 43rd country in the world in terms of installed solar energy (1.0 GW).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[269]</a></sup> The wind potential of the Patagonia region is considered gigantic, with estimates that the area could provide enough electricity to sustain the consumption of a country like Brazil alone. However, Argentina has infrastructural deficiencies to carry out the transmission of electricity from uninhabited areas with a lot of wind to the great centers of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[270]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Argentina" title="Science and technology in Argentina">Science and technology in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg"><img alt="Team of astronauts" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1805" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg/220px-Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg/330px-Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg/440px-Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President Macri in the <a href="/wiki/INVAP" title="INVAP">INVAP</a> with the <a href="/wiki/SAOCOM" title="SAOCOM">SAOCOM</a> A and B, two planned <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">Earth observation satellite</a> <a href="/wiki/Satellite_constellation" title="Satellite constellation">constellation</a> of Argentine <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_Agency" title="Space Agency">Space Agency</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CONAE" title="CONAE">CONAE</a>. the scheduled launch dates for 1A and 1B were further pushed back to 2018 and 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[271]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Argentines have received three <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prizes</a> in the Sciences. <a href="/wiki/Bernardo_Houssay" title="Bernardo Houssay">Bernardo Houssay</a>, the first Latin American recipient, discovered the role of <a href="/wiki/Pituitary_gland" title="Pituitary gland">pituitary hormones</a> in regulating <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> in animals, and shared the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine</a> in 1947. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luis_Leloir" title="Luis Leloir">Luis Leloir</a> discovered how organisms store energy converting glucose into <a href="/wiki/Glycogen" title="Glycogen">glycogen</a> and the compounds which are fundamental in <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolizing</a> <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a>, receiving the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> in 1970. <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Milstein" title="César Milstein">César Milstein</a> did extensive research in <a href="/wiki/Antibody" title="Antibody">antibodies</a>, sharing the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1984. Argentine research has led to treatments for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heart_disease" title="Heart disease">heart diseases</a> and several forms of cancer. <a href="/wiki/Domingo_Liotta" title="Domingo Liotta">Domingo Liotta</a> designed and developed the first <a href="/wiki/Artificial_heart" title="Artificial heart">artificial heart</a> that was successfully implanted in a human being in 1969. <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Favaloro" title="René Favaloro">René Favaloro</a> developed the techniques and performed the world's first <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_bypass_surgery" title="Coronary artery bypass surgery">coronary bypass surgery</a>.
</p><p>Argentina's nuclear programme has been highly successful. In 1957 Argentina was the first country in Latin America to design and build a <a href="/wiki/Research_reactor" title="Research reactor">research reactor</a> with homegrown technology, the <a href="/wiki/RA-1_Enrico_Fermi" title="RA-1 Enrico Fermi">RA-1 Enrico Fermi</a>. This reliance in the development of own nuclear related technologies, instead of simply buying them abroad, was a constant of Argentina's nuclear programme conducted by the civilian <a href="/wiki/National_Atomic_Energy_Commission" title="National Atomic Energy Commission">National Atomic Energy Commission</a> (CNEA). Nuclear facilities with Argentine technology have been built in Peru, Algeria, Australia and Egypt. In 1983, the country admitted having the capability of producing weapon-grade <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, a major step needed to assemble <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapons</a>; since then, however, Argentina has pledged to use nuclear power only for peaceful purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[272]</a></sup> As a member of the Board of Governors of the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a>, Argentina has been a strong voice in support of nuclear non-proliferation efforts<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[273]</a></sup> and is highly committed to global nuclear security.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[274]</a></sup> In 1974 it was the first country in Latin America to put in-line a commercial nuclear power plant, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atucha_I_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Atucha I Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha I</a>. Although the Argentine built parts for that station amounted to 10% of the total, the nuclear fuel it uses are since entirely built in the country. Later nuclear power stations employed a higher percentage of Argentine built components; <a href="/wiki/Embalse_Nuclear_Power_Station" title="Embalse Nuclear Power Station">Embalse</a>, finished in 1983, a 30% and the 2011 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atucha_II_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Atucha II Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha II</a> reactor a 40%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite its modest budget and numerous setbacks, academics and the sciences in Argentina have enjoyed an international respect since the turn of the 1900s, when <a href="/wiki/Luis_Agote" title="Luis Agote">Luis Agote</a> devised the first safe and effective means of <a href="/wiki/Blood_transfusion" title="Blood transfusion">blood transfusion</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Favaloro" title="René Favaloro">René Favaloro</a>, who was a pioneer in the improvement of the <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_bypass_surgery" title="Coronary artery bypass surgery">coronary artery bypass surgery</a>. Argentine scientists are still on the cutting edge in fields such as <a href="/wiki/Nanotechnology" title="Nanotechnology">nanotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">computer sciences</a>, molecular biology, oncology, ecology and cardiology. <a href="/wiki/Juan_Maldacena" title="Juan Maldacena">Juan Maldacena</a>, an Argentine-American scientist, is a leading figure in <a href="/wiki/String_theory" title="String theory">string theory</a>.
</p><p>Space research has also become increasingly active in Argentina. Argentine built satellites include LUSAT-1 (1990), Víctor-1 (1996), PEHUENSAT-1 (2007),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[276]</a></sup> and those developed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CONAE" title="CONAE">CONAE</a>, the Argentine space agency, of the SAC series.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[277]</a></sup> Argentina has its own satellite programme, nuclear power station designs (4th generation) and public nuclear energy company <a href="/wiki/INVAP" title="INVAP">INVAP</a>, which provides several countries with nuclear reactors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-science_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-science-294">[278]</a></sup> Established in 1991, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CONAE" title="CONAE">CONAE</a> has since launched two satellites successfully and,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[279]</a></sup> in June 2009, secured an agreement with the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> for the installation of a 35-m diameter antenna and other mission support facilities at the <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Auger_Observatory" title="Pierre Auger Observatory">Pierre Auger Observatory</a>, the world's foremost <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_ray" title="Cosmic ray">cosmic ray</a> observatory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[280]</a></sup> The facility will contribute to numerous ESA space probes, as well as CONAE's own, domestic research projects. Chosen from 20 potential sites and one of only three such ESA installations in the world, the new antenna will create a triangulation which will allow the ESA to ensure mission coverage around the clock<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[281]</a></sup> Argentina was ranked 73rd in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[285]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_communications">Media and communications</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Argentina" title="Communications in Argentina">Communications in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Estudio_Pais1.JPG"><img alt="TV Studio." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Estudio_Pais1.JPG/220px-Estudio_Pais1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Estudio_Pais1.JPG/330px-Estudio_Pais1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Estudio_Pais1.JPG/440px-Estudio_Pais1.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Estudio_Pais1.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"<i>Estudio País 24, the Program of the Argentines</i>" in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TV_P%C3%BAblica_Digital_(Argentina)" title="TV Pública Digital (Argentina)">Channel 7</a>, the first television station in the country</div></div></div>
<p>Print media industry is highly developed in Argentina, with more than two hundred newspapers. The major national ones include <i><a href="/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper)" title="Clarín (Argentine newspaper)">Clarín</a></i> (centrist, Latin America's best-seller and the second most widely circulated in the Spanish-speaking world), <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Naci%C3%B3n_(Buenos_Aires)" title="La Nación (Buenos Aires)">La Nación</a></i> (centre-right, published since 1870), <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C3%A1gina/12" title="Página/12">Página/12</a></i> (leftist, founded in 1987), <i><a href="/wiki/La_Voz_del_Interior" title="La Voz del Interior">La Voz del Interior</a></i> (centre, founded in 1904),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200045_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200045-302">[286]</a></sup> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Argentinisches_Tageblatt" title="Argentinisches Tageblatt">Argentinisches Tageblatt</a></i> (German weekly, liberal, published since 1878)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAkstinat201320_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAkstinat201320-303">[287]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina began <a href="/wiki/History_of_radio" title="History of radio">the world's first regular radio broadcasting</a> on 27 August 1920, when <a href="/wiki/Richard_Wagner" title="Richard Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Parsifal" title="Parsifal">Parsifal</a></i> was aired by a team of medical students led by <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Tel%C3%A9maco_Susini" title="Enrique Telémaco Susini">Enrique Telémaco Susini</a> in Buenos Aires' <a href="/wiki/Teatro_Coliseo" title="Teatro Coliseo">Teatro Coliseo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[288]</a></sup> By 2002<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were 260 <a href="/wiki/AM_broadcasting" title="AM broadcasting">AM</a> and 1150 <a href="/wiki/FM_broadcasting" title="FM broadcasting">FM</a> registered radio stations in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Argentina" title="Television in Argentina">Argentine television</a> industry is large, diverse and popular across Latin America, with many productions and <a href="/wiki/TV_format" title="TV format">TV formats</a> having been exported abroad. Since 1999 Argentines enjoy the highest availability of cable and satellite television in Latin America,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[290]</a></sup> as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> totaling 87.4% of the country's households, a rate similar to those in the United States, Canada and Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[291]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Argentina also had the highest coverage of networked telecommunications among Latin American powers: about 67% of its population had internet access and 137.2%, mobile phone subscriptions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[292]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="973" data-file-width="534" decoding="async" height="310" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png/170px-Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png/255px-Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png/340px-Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Argentina_provinces_by_population_2010.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Argentine provinces by population (2010)</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Argentina" title="Demographics of Argentina">Demographics of Argentina</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Argentines" title="Argentines">Argentines</a></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INDEC" title="INDEC">2010 census</a> counted 40,117,096 inhabitants, up from 36,260,130 in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[294]</a></sup> Argentina ranks third in South America in total population, fourth in Latin America and 33rd globally. Its population density of 15 persons per square kilometer of land area is well below the world average of 50 persons. The population growth rate in 2010 was an estimated 1.03% annually, with a birth rate of 17.7 live births per 1,000 inhabitants and a mortality rate of 7.4 deaths per 1,000 inhabitants. Since 2010, the crude <a href="/wiki/Net_migration_rate" title="Net migration rate">net migration rate</a> has ranged from below zero to up to four immigrants per 1,000 inhabitants per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentina is in the midst of a <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">demographic transition</a> to an older and slower-growing population. The proportion of people under 15 is 25.6%, a little below the world average of 28%, and the proportion of people 65 and older is relatively high at 10.8%. In Latin America this is second only to <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> and well above the world average, which is currently 7%. Has a comparatively low <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" title="Infant mortality rate">infant mortality rate</a>. Its birth rate of 2.3 children per woman is considerably below the high of 7.0 children born per woman in 1895,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[296]</a></sup> though still nearly twice as high as in Spain or Italy, which are culturally and demographically similar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[298]</a></sup> The median age is 31.9 years and <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> at birth is 77.14 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[299]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, Argentina became the first country in Latin America, the second in the Americas, and the tenth worldwide to legalize same-sex marriage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[301]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnography">Ethnography</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnography_of_Argentina" title="Ethnography of Argentina">Ethnography of Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Argentina" title="Immigration to Argentina">Immigration to Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3006" data-file-width="2399" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG/170px-XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG/255px-XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG/340px-XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Over 25 million Argentines have at least one <a href="/wiki/Italian_Argentines" title="Italian Argentines">Italian immigrant ancestor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LaMatanza_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-LaMatanza-26">[20]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Argentina is considered a country of immigrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encuesta_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-encuesta-318">[302]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coke_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coke-319">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[304]</a></sup> Argentines usually refer to the country as a <i>crisol de razas</i> (crucible of races, or <a href="/wiki/Melting_pot" title="Melting pot">melting pot</a>).
</p><p>In colonial times, the ethnic composition of Argentina was the result of the interaction of the pre-Columbian indigenous population with a colonizing population of Spanish origin and with sub-Saharan African slaves. Before the middle 19th century, the ethnic make up of Argentina was very similar to that of other countries of <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-structure_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-structure-322">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 1857 and 1950 Argentina was the country with the second biggest immigration wave in the world, at 6.6 million, second only to the United States in the numbers of immigrants received (27 million) and ahead of other areas of new settlement like Canada, Brazil and Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ref1_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-ref1-325">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ref2_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-ref2-326">[310]</a></sup> However, mass European immigration did not have the same impact in the whole country. According to the 1914 national census, 30% of Argentina's population was foreign-born, including 50% of the people in the city of Buenos Aires, but foreigners were only 2% in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Catamarca_Province" title="Catamarca Province">Catamarca</a> and <a href="/wiki/La_Rioja_Province,_Argentina" title="La Rioja Province, Argentina">La Rioja</a> (North West region).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-structure_322-1"><a href="#cite_note-structure-322">[306]</a></sup>
</p><p>Strikingly, at those times, the national population doubled every two decades. This belief is endured in the popular saying <i>"los argentinos descienden de los barcos"</i> (Argentines descend from the ships). Therefore, most Argentines are descended from the 19th- and 20th-century immigrants of the <a href="/wiki/Great_European_immigration_wave_to_Argentina" title="Great European immigration wave to Argentina">great European immigration wave to Argentina</a> (1850–1955),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lizcano_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lizcano-327">[311]</a></sup> with a great majority of these immigrants coming from diverse European countries, particularly Italy and Spain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ref1_325-1"><a href="#cite_note-ref1-325">[309]</a></sup> The majority of Argentines descend from multiple European ethnic groups, primarily of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_people" title="Italian people">Italian</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_people" title="Spanish people">Spanish</a> descent, with over 25 million Argentines (almost 60% of the population) having some partial Italian origins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[312]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4400" data-file-width="5747" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg/220px-Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg/330px-Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg/440px-Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Macri_con_F%C3%A9lix_Diaz.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The cacique <a href="/wiki/Toba_people" title="Toba people">Qom</a> <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_D%C3%ADaz_(cacique)" title="Félix Díaz (cacique)">Félix Díaz</a> meets with then president Mauricio Macri.</div></div></div>
<p>Argentina is also home to a notable <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_Argentine" title="Asian Argentine">Asian</a> population, the majority of whom are descended from either West Asians (namely <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_people" title="Lebanese people">Lebanese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syrians" title="Syrians">Syrians</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lizcano2007_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lizcano2007-329">[313]</a></sup> or East Asians (such as the Chinese,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[314]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_people" title="Korean people">Koreans</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[315]</a></sup> The latter of whom number at around 180,000 individuals. The total number of <a href="/wiki/Arab_Argentines" title="Arab Argentines">Arab Argentines</a> (most of whom are of Lebanese or Syrian origin) is estimated to be 1.3 to 3.5 million. Many immigrated from various Asian countries to Argentina during the 19th century (especially during the latter half of the century) and the first half of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elindependiente_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-Elindependiente-332">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[317]</a></sup> Most Arab Argentines are <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> belonging to the Catholic Church (the Latin Rite church and Eastern Rite churches), and Eastern Orthodox churches. A minority are <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a>.
</p><p>A 2010 study conducted on 218 individuals by the Argentine geneticist <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Daniel_Corach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Daniel Corach (page does not exist)">Daniel Corach</a> established that the genetic map of Argentina is composed of 79% from different European ethnicities (mainly Italian and Spanish), 18% of different indigenous ethnicities, and 4.3% of African ethnic groups; 63.6% of the tested group had at least one ancestor who was <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Argentina" title="Indigenous peoples in Argentina">Indigenous</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-onlinelibrary.wiley.com_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-onlinelibrary.wiley.com-334">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 1970s, immigration has mostly been coming from <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>, with smaller numbers from the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican Republic</a>, Ecuador and <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[320]</a></sup> The Argentine government estimates that 750,000 inhabitants lack official documents and has launched a program<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[321]</a></sup> to encourage illegal immigrants to declare their status in return for two-year residence visas—so far over 670,000 applications have been processed under the program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[322]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Argentina" title="Languages of Argentina">Languages of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5069" data-file-width="2980" decoding="async" height="289" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png/170px-Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png/255px-Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png/340px-Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dialectos_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Dialectal variants of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish language</a> in Argentina</div></div></div>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[M]</a></sup> official language is <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, spoken by almost all Argentines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup>
The country is the largest <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">Spanish-speaking society</a> that universally employs <i><a href="/wiki/Voseo" title="Voseo">voseo</a></i>, the use of the <a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">pronoun</a> <i>vos</i> instead of <i>tú</i> ("you"), which imposes the use of alternative verb forms as well.
Owing to the extensive Argentine geography, Spanish has a strong variation among regions, although the prevalent dialect is <i><a href="/wiki/Rioplatense_Spanish" title="Rioplatense Spanish">Rioplatense</a></i>, primarily spoken in the Pampean and Patagonian regions and accented similarly to the <a href="/wiki/Neapolitan_language" title="Neapolitan language">Neapolitan language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEColantoniGurlekian2004107–119_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEColantoniGurlekian2004107–119-341">[324]</a></sup> Italian and other European immigrants influenced <i><a href="/wiki/Lunfardo" title="Lunfardo">Lunfardo</a></i>—the regional slang—permeating the vernacular vocabulary of other Latin American countries as well.
</p><p>There are several second-languages in widespread use among the Argentine population: English (<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[N]</a></sup> taught since <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Elementary_school" title="Elementary school">elementary school</a>; 42.3% of Argentines claim to speak it, with 15.4% of them claiming to have a high level of language comprehension.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>); <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a> (by 1.5 million people);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[O]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> (specially its <a href="/wiki/Levantine_Arabic" title="Levantine Arabic">Northern Levantine dialect</a>, by one million people);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Standard_German" title="Standard German">Standard German</a> (by 200,000 people);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[P]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Guarani_language" title="Guarani language">Guaraní</a> (by 200,000 people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> mostly in Corrientes and Misiones);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Corrientes-5598_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-Corrientes-5598-5">[3]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">Catalan</a> (by 174,000 people);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quechua_language" title="Quechua language">Quechua</a> (by 65,000 people, mostly in the Northwest);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wich%C3%AD_languages" title="Wichí languages">Wichí</a> (by 53,700 people, mainly in Chaco<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> where, along with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kom_language_(South_America)" title="Kom language (South America)">Kom</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moqoit_language" title="Moqoit language">Moqoit</a>, it is official <i>de jure</i>);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kom_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-kom-7">[5]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vlax_Romani_language" title="Vlax Romani language">Vlax Romani</a> (by 52,000 people);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_South_America" title="Albanians in South America">40,000 people</a>);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[325]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a> (by 32,000 people);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-9"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aymara_language" title="Aymara language">Aymara</a> (by 30,000 people, mostly in the Northwest);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-10"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> (by 27,000 people);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-11"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> (5,000 people in Patagonia);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_340-12"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-340">[323]</a></sup> and some districts also have incorporated it as an educational language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips2000602_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips2000602-346">[326]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
