<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Argentina" title="Religion in Argentina">Religion in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Francis_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1392" data-file-width="928" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Francis_2013.jpg/170px-Francis_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Francis_2013.jpg/255px-Francis_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Francis_2013.jpg/340px-Francis_2013.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Francis_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Francis</a>, the first pope from the Americas, was born and raised in Argentina.</div></div></div>
<p>The Constitution guarantees <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._14,_20_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._14,_20-347">[327]</a></sup> Although it enforces neither an official nor a state faith,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFayt1985347Bidart_Campos200553_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFayt1985347Bidart_Campos200553-348">[328]</a></sup> it gives <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a> a preferential status.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._2_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._2-349">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[Q]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a 2008 CONICET poll, Argentines were 76.5% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic" title="Catholic">Catholic</a>, 11.3% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agnostic" title="Agnostic">Agnostics</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist">Atheists</a>, 9% <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">Evangelical Protestants</a>, 1.2% <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, and 0.9% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mormon" title="Mormon">Mormons</a>, while 1.2% followed other religions, including <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal20089_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal20089-352">[331]</a></sup> These figures appear to have changed quite significantly in recent years: data recorded in 2017 indicated that Catholics made up 66% of the population, indicating a drop of 10.5% in nine years, and the nonreligious in the country standing at 21% of the population, indicating an almost doubling over the same period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Latinobarometro_2017_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-Latinobarometro_2017-353">[332]</a></sup>
</p><p>The country is home to both the <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Argentina" title="Islam in Argentina">largest Muslim</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irfr1_350-1"><a href="#cite_note-irfr1-350">[330]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Argentine" title="Jewish Argentine">largest Jewish</a> communities in Latin America, the latter being the seventh most populous in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDellaPergola201350_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDellaPergola201350-354">[333]</a></sup> Argentina is a member of the <a href="/wiki/International_Holocaust_Remembrance_Alliance" title="International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance">International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irfr1_350-2"><a href="#cite_note-irfr1-350">[330]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentines show high individualization and de-institutionalization of religious beliefs;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200821_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200821-355">[334]</a></sup> 23.8% claim to always attend religious services; 49.1% seldom do and 26.8% never do.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200824_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200824-356">[335]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 13 March 2013, Argentine <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Jorge Mario Bergoglio</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cardinal_(Catholicism)" title="Cardinal (Catholicism)">Cardinal</a> <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Buenos_Aires" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Buenos Aires">Archbishop of Buenos Aires</a>, was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Papal_conclave,_2013" title="Papal conclave, 2013">elected</a> <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Bishop of Rome</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supreme_Pontiff" title="Supreme Pontiff">Supreme Pontiff</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>. He took the name "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Francis_of_Assisi" title="St. Francis of Assisi">Francis</a>", and he became the first Pope from either the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> or from the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>; he is the first Pope born outside of Europe since the <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave" title="Papal conclave">election</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_III" title="Pope Gregory III">Pope Gregory III</a> (who was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian" title="Syrian">Syrian</a>) in 741.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[336]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">Health care</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Argentina" title="Health care in Argentina">Health care in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2134" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg/220px-Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg/330px-Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg/440px-Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The University of Buenos Aires School of Medicine, alma mater to many of the country's 3,000 medical graduates, annually<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[337]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Health care is provided through a combination of employer and labour union-sponsored plans (<i>Obras Sociales</i>), government insurance plans, public hospitals and clinics and through private health insurance plans. Health care cooperatives number over 300 (of which 200 are related to <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">labour unions</a>) and provide health care for half the population; the national INSSJP (popularly known as PAMI) covers nearly all of the five million senior citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iadb_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-iadb-359">[338]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are more than 153,000 hospital beds, 121,000 physicians and 37,000 dentists (ratios comparable to <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed nations</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-deis_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-deis-360">[339]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-undata_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-undata-361">[340]</a></sup> The relatively high access to medical care has historically resulted in mortality patterns and trends similar to developed nations': from 1953 to 2005, deaths from <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular disease</a> increased from 20% to 23% of the total, those from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tumors" title="Tumors">tumors</a> from 14% to 20%, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Respiratory" title="Respiratory">respiratory</a> problems from 7% to 14%, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digestive_system" title="Digestive system">digestive</a> maladies (non-infectious) from 7% to 11%, strokes a steady 7%, injuries, 6%, and <a href="/wiki/Infection" title="Infection">infectious</a> diseases, 4%. Causes related to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senility" title="Senility">senility</a> led to many of the rest. Infant deaths have fallen from 19% of all deaths in 1953 to 3% in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-deis_360-1"><a href="#cite_note-deis-360">[339]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-un57_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-un57-362">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>The availability of health care has also reduced <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> from 70 per 1000 live births in 1948<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-un97_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-un97-363">[342]</a></sup> to 12.1 in 2009<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-deis_360-2"><a href="#cite_note-deis-360">[339]</a></sup> and raised <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> at birth from 60 years to 76.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-un97_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-un97-363">[342]</a></sup> Though these figures compare favorably with global averages, they fall short of levels in developed nations and in 2006, Argentina ranked fourth in Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-undata_361-1"><a href="#cite_note-undata-361">[340]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Argentina" title="Education in Argentina">Education in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="720" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg/220px-UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg/330px-UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg/440px-UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UBA-Facultad-Derecho.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Faculty of Law of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Buenos_Aires" title="University of Buenos Aires">University of Buenos Aires</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Argentine education system consists of four levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[343]</a></sup> An initial level for children between 45 days to 5 years old, with the last two years<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[344]</a></sup> being compulsory. An elementary or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lower_school" title="Lower school">lower school</a> mandatory level lasting 6 or 7 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leveldiff_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-leveldiff-366">[R]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> was 98.07%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educ1_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-educ1-367">[345]</a></sup> A secondary or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_school" title="High school">high school</a> mandatory level lasting 5 or 6 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leveldiff_366-1"><a href="#cite_note-leveldiff-366">[R]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> 38.5% of people over age 20 had completed secondary school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educ2_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-educ2-368">[346]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher level</a>, divided in tertiary, university and post-graduate sub-levels. in 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were 47 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Argentine_universities" title="List of Argentine universities">national public universities</a> across the country, as well as 46 private ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[347]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> 7.1% of people over age 20 had graduated from university.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educ2_368-1"><a href="#cite_note-educ2-368">[346]</a></sup> The public universities of <a href="/wiki/University_of_Buenos_Aires" title="University of Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universidad_Nacional_de_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Universidad Nacional de Córdoba">Córdoba</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universidad_Nacional_de_La_Plata" title="Universidad Nacional de La Plata">La Plata</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universidad_Nacional_de_Rosario" title="Universidad Nacional de Rosario">Rosario</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/National_Technological_University" title="National Technological University">National Technological University</a> are some of the most important. The Argentine state guarantees universal, secular and free-of-charge public education for all levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[S]</a></sup> Responsibility for educational supervision is organized at the federal and individual provincial states. In the last decades the role of the private sector has grown across all educational stages.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Argentina_by_population" title="List of cities in Argentina by population">List of cities in Argentina by population</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Argentina" title="List of cities in Argentina">List of cities in Argentina</a></div>
<p>Argentina is highly urbanized, with 92% of its population living in cities:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[348]</a></sup> the ten largest metropolitan areas account for half of the population.
About 3 million people live in the city of Buenos Aires, and including the Greater Buenos Aires metropolitan area it totals around 13 million, making it one of the largest urban areas in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-majorcities_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-majorcities-372">[349]</a></sup> The metropolitan areas of Córdoba and Rosario have around 1.3 million inhabitants each.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-majorcities_372-1"><a href="#cite_note-majorcities-372">[349]</a></sup> Mendoza, San Miguel de Tucumán, La Plata, Mar del Plata, Salta and Santa Fe have at least half a million people each.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-majorcities_372-2"><a href="#cite_note-majorcities-372">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>The population is unequally distributed: about 60% live in the Pampas region (21% of the total area), including 15 million people in Buenos Aires province. The provinces of Córdoba and Santa Fe, and the city of Buenos Aires have 3 million each. Seven other provinces have over one million people each: Mendoza, Tucumán, Entre Ríos, Salta, Chaco, Corrientes and Misiones. With 64.3 inhabitants per square kilometre (167/sq mi), Tucumán is the only Argentine province more densely populated than the world average; by contrast, the southern province of Santa Cruz has around 1.1/km<sup>2</sup> (2.8/sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[350]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Argentina" title="Culture of Argentina">Culture of Argentina</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Argentines" title="List of Argentines">List of Argentines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="612" data-file-width="612" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png/170px-Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png/255px-Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png/340px-Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sol_de_mayo_moneda.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sun_of_May" title="Sun of May">Sun of May</a> on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asamblea_del_A%C3%B1o_XIII" title="Asamblea del Año XIII">first Argentine coin</a>, 1813</div></div></div>
<p>Argentina is a <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multicultural country</a> with significant European influences. Modern Argentine culture has been largely influenced by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_people" title="Italian people">Italian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_people" title="Spanish people">Spanish</a> and other European immigration from <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Northern_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland">United Kingdom</a>, among others. Its cities are largely characterized by both the prevalence of people of European descent, and of conscious imitation of American and European styles in fashion, architecture and design.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frommer_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-frommer-375">[352]</a></sup> Museums, cinemas, and galleries are abundant in all the large urban centres, as well as traditional establishments such as literary bars, or bars offering <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Live_music" title="Live music">live music</a> of a variety of genres although there are lesser elements of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amerindian" title="Amerindian">Amerindian</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_culture" title="African culture">African</a> influences, particularly in the fields of music and art. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200691_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200691-376">[353]</a></sup> The other big influence is the <a href="/wiki/Gaucho" title="Gaucho">gauchos</a> and their traditional country lifestyle of self-reliance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford2006123_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford2006123-377">[354]</a></sup> Finally, indigenous American traditions have been absorbed into the general cultural milieu.
Argentine writer <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Sabato" title="Ernesto Sabato">Ernesto Sabato</a> has reflected on the nature of the culture of Argentina as follows:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>With the primitive Hispanic American reality fractured in La Plata Basin due to immigration, its inhabitants have come to be somewhat dual with all the dangers but also with all the advantages of that condition: because of our European roots, we deeply link the nation with the enduring values of the Old World; because of our condition of Americans we link ourselves to the rest of the continent, through the folklore of the interior and the old Castilian that unifies us, feeling somehow the vocation of the <i>Patria Grande</i> San Martín and Bolívar once imagined.
</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Sabato" title="Ernesto Sabato">Ernesto Sabato</a>, <i>La cultura en la encrucijada nacional</i> (1976)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[355]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Argentine_literature" title="Argentine literature">Argentine literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Argentine_literature.jpg"><img alt="Mosaic image showing the four photographs" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1476" data-file-width="1181" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Argentine_literature.jpg/170px-Argentine_literature.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Argentine_literature.jpg/255px-Argentine_literature.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Argentine_literature.jpg/340px-Argentine_literature.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Argentine_literature.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Four of the most influential Argentine writers. Top-left to bottom-right: <a href="/wiki/Julio_Cort%C3%A1zar" title="Julio Cortázar">Julio Cortázar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Ocampo" title="Victoria Ocampo">Victoria Ocampo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Luis_Borges" title="Jorge Luis Borges">Jorge Luis Borges</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adolfo_Bioy_Casares" title="Adolfo Bioy Casares">Adolfo Bioy Casares</a></div></div></div>
<p>Although Argentina's rich literary history began around 1550,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERivas198911_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERivas198911-379">[356]</a></sup> it reached full independence with <a href="/wiki/Esteban_Echeverr%C3%ADa" title="Esteban Echeverría">Esteban Echeverría</a>'s <i>El Matadero</i>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romantic_literature" title="Romantic literature">romantic</a> landmark that played a significant role in the development of 19th century's Argentine narrative,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199899_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199899-380">[357]</a></sup> split by the ideological divide between the popular, federalist epic of <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Hern%C3%A1ndez_(writer)" title="José Hernández (writer)">José Hernández</a>' <i><a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Fierro" title="Martín Fierro">Martín Fierro</a></i> and the elitist and cultured discourse of <a href="/wiki/Domingo_Faustino_Sarmiento" title="Domingo Faustino Sarmiento">Sarmiento</a>'s masterpiece, <i><a href="/wiki/Facundo" title="Facundo">Facundo</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199813,_101YoungCisneros201051_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199813,_101YoungCisneros201051-381">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modernist_literature" title="Modernist literature">Modernist</a> movement advanced into the 20th century including exponents such as <a href="/wiki/Leopoldo_Lugones" title="Leopoldo Lugones">Leopoldo Lugones</a> and poet <a href="/wiki/Alfonsina_Storni" title="Alfonsina Storni">Alfonsina Storni</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros201051–52_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros201051–52-382">[359]</a></sup> it was followed by <a href="/wiki/Vanguardism" title="Vanguardism">Vanguardism</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Ricardo_G%C3%BCiraldes" title="Ricardo Güiraldes">Ricardo Güiraldes</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Don_Segundo_Sombra" title="Don Segundo Sombra">Don Segundo Sombra</a></i> as an important reference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart1998104,_107–09YoungCisneros2010223_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart1998104,_107–09YoungCisneros2010223-383">[360]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Jorge_Luis_Borges" title="Jorge Luis Borges">Jorge Luis Borges</a>, Argentina's most acclaimed writer and one of the foremost figures in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_literature" title="History of literature">history of literature</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBloom19942_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBloom19942-384">[361]</a></sup> found new ways of looking at the modern world in <a href="/wiki/Metaphor" title="Metaphor">metaphor</a> and philosophical debate and his influence has extended to authors all over the globe. Short stories such as <i><a href="/wiki/Ficciones" title="Ficciones">Ficciones</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Aleph_(short_story_collection)" title="The Aleph (short story collection)">The Aleph</a></i> are among his most famous works. He was a friend and collaborator of <a href="/wiki/Adolfo_Bioy_Casares" title="Adolfo Bioy Casares">Adolfo Bioy Casares</a>, who wrote one of the most praised <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> <a href="/wiki/Novel" title="Novel">novels</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Invention_of_Morel" title="The Invention of Morel">The Invention of Morel</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros201052,_80_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros201052,_80-385">[362]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Julio_Cort%C3%A1zar" title="Julio Cortázar">Julio Cortázar</a>, one of the leading members of the <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Boom" title="Latin American Boom">Latin American Boom</a> and a major name in 20th century literature,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros201079,_144_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros201079,_144-386">[363]</a></sup> influenced an entire generation of writers in the Americas and Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros20103,_144_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoungCisneros20103,_144-387">[364]</a></sup>
</p><p>A remarkable episode in the Argentine literature's history is the social and literarial dialectica between the so-called <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grupo_Florida" title="es:Grupo Florida">Florida Group</a> named this way because its members used to meet together at the <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confiter%C3%ADa_Richmond" title="es:Confitería Richmond">Richmond Cafeteria</a> at Florida street and published in the <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Fierro_(Revista)" title="es:Martín Fierro (Revista)">Martin Fierro magazine</a>, like <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Luis_Borges" title="Jorge Luis Borges">Jorge Luis Borges</a>, <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopoldo_Marechal" title="es:Leopoldo Marechal">Leopoldo Marechal</a>, <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Berni" title="es:Antonio Berni">Antonio Berni</a> (artist), among others, versus the <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grupo_Boedo" title="es:Grupo Boedo">Boedo Group</a> of <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Arlt" title="Roberto Arlt">Roberto Arlt</a>,
<a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesar_Tiempo" title="es:Cesar Tiempo">Cesar Tiempo</a>,
<a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homero_Manzi" title="es:Homero Manzi">Homero Manzi</a> (tango composer), that used to meet at the
<a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_El_Japon%C3%A9s" title="es:Café El Japonés">Japanese Cafe</a> and published their works with the <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Editorial_Claridad" title="es:Editorial Claridad">Editorial Claridad</a>, with both the cafe and the publisher located at the Boedo Avenue.
</p><p>Other highly regarded Argentine writers, poets and <a href="/wiki/Essay" title="Essay">essayists</a> include <a href="/wiki/Estanislao_del_Campo" title="Estanislao del Campo">Estanislao del Campo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Cambaceres" title="Eugenio Cambaceres">Eugenio Cambaceres</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Bonifacio_Palacios" title="Pedro Bonifacio Palacios">Pedro Bonifacio Palacios</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Wast" title="Hugo Wast">Hugo Wast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benito_Lynch" title="Benito Lynch">Benito Lynch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Banchs" title="Enrique Banchs">Enrique Banchs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oliverio_Girondo" title="Oliverio Girondo">Oliverio Girondo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ezequiel_Mart%C3%ADnez_Estrada" title="Ezequiel Martínez Estrada">Ezequiel Martínez Estrada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Ocampo" title="Victoria Ocampo">Victoria Ocampo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leopoldo_Marechal" title="Leopoldo Marechal">Leopoldo Marechal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silvina_Ocampo" title="Silvina Ocampo">Silvina Ocampo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Arlt" title="Roberto Arlt">Roberto Arlt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Mallea" title="Eduardo Mallea">Eduardo Mallea</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manuel_Mujica_L%C3%A1inez" title="Manuel Mujica Láinez">Manuel Mujica Láinez</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ernesto_S%C3%A1bato" title="Ernesto Sábato">Ernesto Sábato</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silvina_Bullrich" title="Silvina Bullrich">Silvina Bullrich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rodolfo_Walsh" title="Rodolfo Walsh">Rodolfo Walsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_Elena_Walsh" title="María Elena Walsh">María Elena Walsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Eloy_Mart%C3%ADnez" title="Tomás Eloy Martínez">Tomás Eloy Martínez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Puig" title="Manuel Puig">Manuel Puig</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alejandra_Pizarnik" title="Alejandra Pizarnik">Alejandra Pizarnik</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Osvaldo_Soriano" title="Osvaldo Soriano">Osvaldo Soriano</a>.
<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199866,_85,_97–121McCloskeyBurford200643Díaz_Alejandro197022,_91YoungCisneros201051–54_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199866,_85,_97–121McCloskeyBurford200643Díaz_Alejandro197022,_91YoungCisneros201051–54-388">[365]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Argentina" title="Music of Argentina">Music of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Gardel,_Argentine_tango_singer,_portrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1573" data-file-width="1031" decoding="async" height="259" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Carlos_Gardel%2C_Argentine_tango_singer%2C_portrait.jpg/170px-Carlos_Gardel%2C_Argentine_tango_singer%2C_portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Carlos_Gardel%2C_Argentine_tango_singer%2C_portrait.jpg/255px-Carlos_Gardel%2C_Argentine_tango_singer%2C_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Carlos_Gardel%2C_Argentine_tango_singer%2C_portrait.jpg/340px-Carlos_Gardel%2C_Argentine_tango_singer%2C_portrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Gardel,_Argentine_tango_singer,_portrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Carlos_Gardel" title="Carlos Gardel">Carlos Gardel</a>, the most prominent figure in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_tango" title="History of tango">history of tango</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tango" title="Tango">Tango</a>, a <i><a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Río de la Plata">Rioplatense</a></i> musical genre with European and African influences,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller200486_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller200486-389">[366]</a></sup> is one of Argentina's international cultural symbols.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart1998121_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart1998121-390">[367]</a></sup>
The golden age of tango (1930 to mid-1950s) mirrored that of <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swing_music" title="Swing music">swing</a> in the United States, featuring large orchestras like those of <a href="/wiki/Osvaldo_Pugliese" title="Osvaldo Pugliese">Osvaldo Pugliese</a>, <a href="/wiki/An%C3%ADbal_Troilo" title="Aníbal Troilo">Aníbal Troilo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Canaro" title="Francisco Canaro">Francisco Canaro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Julio_de_Caro" title="Julio de Caro">Julio de Caro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juan_d%27Arienzo" title="Juan d'Arienzo">Juan d'Arienzo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643-391">[368]</a></sup>
After 1955, virtuoso <a href="/wiki/Astor_Piazzolla" title="Astor Piazzolla">Astor Piazzolla</a> popularized <i><a href="/wiki/Nuevo_tango" title="Nuevo tango">Nuevo tango</a></i>, a subtler and more intellectual trend for the genre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643_391-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643-391">[368]</a></sup>
Tango enjoys worldwide popularity nowadays with groups like <a href="/wiki/Gotan_Project" title="Gotan Project">Gotan Project</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bajofondo" title="Bajofondo">Bajofondo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tanghetto" title="Tanghetto">Tanghetto</a>.
</p><p>Argentina developed strong classical music and dance scenes that gave rise to renowned artists such as <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Ginastera" title="Alberto Ginastera">Alberto Ginastera</a>, composer; <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Lysy" title="Alberto Lysy">Alberto Lysy</a>, violinist; <a href="/wiki/Martha_Argerich" title="Martha Argerich">Martha Argerich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Delgado" title="Eduardo Delgado">Eduardo Delgado</a>, pianists; <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Barenboim" title="Daniel Barenboim">Daniel Barenboim</a>, pianist and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Symphonic_orchestra" title="Symphonic orchestra">symphonic orchestra</a> director; <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Cura" title="José Cura">José Cura</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_%C3%81lvarez" title="Marcelo Álvarez">Marcelo Álvarez</a>, tenors; and to <a href="/wiki/Ballet_dancer" title="Ballet dancer">ballet dancers</a> <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Donn" title="Jorge Donn">Jorge Donn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Neglia" title="José Neglia">José Neglia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norma_Fontenla" title="Norma Fontenla">Norma Fontenla</a>, <i>Maximiliano Guerra</i>, <a href="/wiki/Paloma_Herrera" title="Paloma Herrera">Paloma Herrera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marianela_N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez" title="Marianela Núñez">Marianela Núñez</a>, <a href="/wiki/I%C3%B1aki_Urlezaga" title="Iñaki Urlezaga">Iñaki Urlezaga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Julio_Bocca" title="Julio Bocca">Julio Bocca</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643_391-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643-391">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>A national Argentine folk style emerged in the 1930s from dozens of regional musical genres and went to influence the entirety of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_American_music" title="Latin American music">Latin American music</a>. Some of its interpreters, like <a href="/wiki/Atahualpa_Yupanqui" title="Atahualpa Yupanqui">Atahualpa Yupanqui</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa" title="Mercedes Sosa">Mercedes Sosa</a>, achieved worldwide acclaim. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romantic_ballad" title="Romantic ballad">romantic ballad</a> genre included singers of international fame such as <a href="/wiki/Sandro_de_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Sandro de América">Sandro de América</a>. <a href="/wiki/Tenor_saxophone" title="Tenor saxophone">Tenor saxophonist</a> <a href="/wiki/Gato_Barbieri" title="Gato Barbieri">Leandro "Gato" Barbieri</a> and composer and <a href="/wiki/Big_band" title="Big band">big band</a> conductor <a href="/wiki/Lalo_Schifrin" title="Lalo Schifrin">Lalo Schifrin</a> are among the most internationally successful Argentine jazz musicians.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Argentine_rock" title="Argentine rock">Argentine rock</a> developed as a distinct musical style in the mid-1960s, when Buenos Aires and Rosario became cradles of aspiring musicians.
Founding bands like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Los_Gatos" title="Los Gatos">Los Gatos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sui_Generis" title="Sui Generis">Sui Generis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Almendra_(band)" title="Almendra (band)">Almendra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manal" title="Manal">Manal</a> were followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seru_Giran" title="Seru Giran">Seru Giran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Los_Abuelos_de_la_Nada" title="Los Abuelos de la Nada">Los Abuelos de la Nada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soda_Stereo" title="Soda Stereo">Soda Stereo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patricio_Rey_y_sus_Redonditos_de_Ricota" title="Patricio Rey y sus Redonditos de Ricota">Patricio Rey y sus Redonditos de Ricota</a>, with prominent artists including <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Cerati" title="Gustavo Cerati">Gustavo Cerati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Litto_Nebbia" title="Litto Nebbia">Litto Nebbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Calamaro" title="Andrés Calamaro">Andrés Calamaro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luis_Alberto_Spinetta" title="Luis Alberto Spinetta">Luis Alberto Spinetta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charly_Garc%C3%ADa" title="Charly García">Charly García</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fito_P%C3%A1ez" title="Fito Páez">Fito Páez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Gieco" title="León Gieco">León Gieco</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643_391-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200643-391">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>A dance and a musical genre popular at the present is <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cachengue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cachengue (page does not exist)">Cachengue</a> a subgenre of <a href="/wiki/Argentine_cumbia" title="Argentine cumbia">Argentine cumbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Reggaeton" title="Reggaeton">reggaeton</a> spreading in popularity in nearby countries such as <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[369]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theatre_and_cinema">Theatre and cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Theatre_in_Argentina" title="Theatre in Argentina">Theatre in Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Argentina" title="Cinema of Argentina">Cinema of Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="750" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg/170px-Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg/255px-Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg/340px-Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Andr%C3%A9s_Muschietti.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Andy_Muschietti" title="Andy Muschietti">Andy Muschietti</a>, director of <i><a href="/wiki/It_(2017_film)" title="It (2017 film)">It</a></i>, the highest-grossing horror film of all-time<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[371]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Buenos Aires is one of the great theatre capitals of the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[372]</a></sup> with a scene of international caliber centered on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corrientes_Avenue" title="Corrientes Avenue">Corrientes Avenue</a>, "the street that never sleeps", sometimes referred to as an intellectual <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a> in Buenos Aires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199848_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFosterLockhartLockhart199848-396">[373]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Teatro_Col%C3%B3n" title="Teatro Colón">Teatro Colón</a> is a global landmark for <a href="/wiki/Opera" title="Opera">opera</a> and classical performances; its acoustics are considered among the world's top five.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELong200921–25_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELong200921–25-397">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[T]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Argentine film industry has historically been one of the three most developed in <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_cinema" title="Latin American cinema">Latin American cinema</a>, along with those produced in <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Mexico" title="Cinema of Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Brazil" title="Cinema of Brazil">Brazil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[376]</a></sup> Started in 1896; by the early 1930s it had already become Latin America's leading film producer, a place it kept until the early 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing200036_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing200036-401">[377]</a></sup> The world's first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_animated_feature_films" title="List of animated feature films">animated feature films</a> were made and released in Argentina, by cartoonist <a href="/wiki/Quirino_Cristiani" title="Quirino Cristiani">Quirino Cristiani</a>, in 1917 and 1918.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[378]</a></sup>
</p><p>Argentine films have achieved worldwide recognition: the country has won two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film</a>, for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Official_Story" title="The Official Story">The Official Story</a></i> (1985) and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Secret_in_Their_Eyes" title="The Secret in Their Eyes">The Secret in Their Eyes</a></i> (2009). In addition, Argentine composers <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luis_Enrique_Bacalov" title="Luis Enrique Bacalov">Luis Enrique Bacalov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Santaolalla" title="Gustavo Santaolalla">Gustavo Santaolalla</a> have been honored with <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Academy Awards for Best Original Score</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Armando_B%C3%B3_(screenwriter)" title="Armando Bó (screenwriter)">Armando Bó</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Giacobone" title="Nicolás Giacobone">Nicolás Giacobone</a> shared in the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay">Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay</a> for 2014. Also, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Argentine" title="French Argentine">Argentine French</a> actress <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9r%C3%A9nice_Bejo" title="Bérénice Bejo">Bérénice Bejo</a> received a nomination for the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress">Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress</a> in 2011 and won the <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Actress" title="César Award for Best Actress">César Award for Best Actress</a> and won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Best_Actress_Award_(Cannes_Film_Festival)" title="Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)">Best Actress</a> award in the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> for her role in the film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Past_(2013_film)" title="The Past (2013 film)">The Past</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CannesAwards_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-CannesAwards-403">[379]</a></sup> Argentina also has won seventeen <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Goya_Award_for_Best_Spanish_Language_Foreign_Film" title="Goya Award for Best Spanish Language Foreign Film">Goya Awards for Best Spanish Language Foreign Film</a>, being by far the most awarded country in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> with twenty-four nominations. Many other Argentine films also have been acclaimed by the international critique. In 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> about 100 full-length motion pictures were being created annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[380]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts_and_architecture">Visual arts and architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Argentine_painting" title="Argentine painting">Argentine painting</a> and <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Argentina" title="Architecture of Argentina">Architecture of Argentina</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="39" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2022</span>)</i></span><span class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<small><a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a></small>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg/220px-Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg/330px-Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg/440px-Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buenos_Aires_-_Las_Nereidas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Las Nereidas Font</i> by <a href="/wiki/Lola_Mora" title="Lola Mora">Lola Mora</a></div></div></div>
<p>Some of the best-known Argentine painters are <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1ndido_L%C3%B3pez" title="Cándido López">Cándido López</a> and <a href="/wiki/Florencio_Molina_Campos" title="Florencio Molina Campos">Florencio Molina Campos</a> (<a href="/wiki/Na%C3%AFve_art" title="Naïve art">Naïve style</a>); <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_de_la_C%C3%A1rcova" title="Ernesto de la Cárcova">Ernesto de la Cárcova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_S%C3%ADvori" title="Eduardo Sívori">Eduardo Sívori</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Realism_(art)" title="Realism (art)">Realism</a>); <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Fader" title="Fernando Fader">Fernando Fader</a> (<a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a>); <a href="/wiki/P%C3%ADo_Collivadino" title="Pío Collivadino">Pío Collivadino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atilio_Malinverno" title="Atilio Malinverno">Atilio Malinverno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ces%C3%A1reo_Bernaldo_de_Quir%C3%B3s" title="Cesáreo Bernaldo de Quirós">Cesáreo Bernaldo de Quirós</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Postimpressionism" title="Postimpressionism">Postimpressionism</a>); <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Pettoruti" title="Emilio Pettoruti">Emilio Pettoruti</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">Cubism</a>); <a href="/wiki/Julio_Barrag%C3%A1n" title="Julio Barragán">Julio Barragán</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Concretism_(art)" title="Concretism (art)">Concretism</a> and Cubism) <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Berni" title="Antonio Berni">Antonio Berni</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neofigurativism" title="Neofigurativism">Neofigurativism</a>); <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Aizenberg" title="Roberto Aizenberg">Roberto Aizenberg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xul_Solar" title="Xul Solar">Xul Solar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Surrealism" title="Surrealism">Surrealism</a>); <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gyula_Ko%C5%A1ice" title="Gyula Košice">Gyula Košice</a> (<a href="/wiki/Constructivism_(art)" title="Constructivism (art)">Constructivism</a>); <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Mac_Entyre" title="Eduardo Mac Entyre">Eduardo Mac Entyre</a> (<a href="/wiki/Generative_art" title="Generative art">Generative art</a>); <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luis_Seoane" title="Luis Seoane">Luis Seoane</a>, <i>Carlos Torrallardona</i>, <i>Luis Aquino</i>, <i>Alfredo Gramajo Gutiérrez</i> (<a href="/wiki/Modernism" title="Modernism">Modernism</a>); <a href="/wiki/Lucio_Fontana" title="Lucio Fontana">Lucio Fontana</a> (<a href="/wiki/Spatialism" title="Spatialism">Spatialism</a>); <a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Maldonado" title="Tomás Maldonado">Tomás Maldonado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Kuitca" title="Guillermo Kuitca">Guillermo Kuitca</a> (<a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">Abstract art</a>); <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Ferrari" title="León Ferrari">León Ferrari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marta_Minuj%C3%ADn" title="Marta Minujín">Marta Minujín</a> (<a href="/wiki/Conceptual_art" title="Conceptual art">Conceptual art</a>); <a href="/wiki/Ciruelo_Cabral" title="Ciruelo Cabral">Gustavo Cabral</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fantasy_art" title="Fantasy art">Fantasy art</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Fabian_Perez" title="Fabian Perez">Fabián Pérez (Neoemotionalism)</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness" title="Wikipedia:Vagueness"><span title="This information is too vague. (February 2022)">vague</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In 1946 Gyula Košice and others created The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mad%C3%AD_Movement" title="Madí Movement">Madí Movement</a> in Argentina, which then spread to Europe and United States, where it had a significant impact.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[381]</a></sup> Tomás Maldonado was one of the main theorists of the <a href="/wiki/Ulm_School_of_Design" title="Ulm School of Design">Ulm Model</a> of design education, still highly influential globally. Other Argentine artists of worldwide fame include <a href="/wiki/Adolfo_Bellocq" title="Adolfo Bellocq">Adolfo Bellocq</a>, whose <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithograph" title="Lithograph">lithographs</a> have been influential since the 1920s, and <a href="/wiki/Benito_Quinquela_Mart%C3%ADn" title="Benito Quinquela Martín">Benito Quinquela Martín</a>, the quintessential port painter, inspired by the immigrant-bound <a href="/wiki/La_Boca" title="La Boca">La Boca</a> neighbourhood. Internationally laureate sculptors <a href="/wiki/Erminio_Blotta" title="Erminio Blotta">Erminio Blotta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lola_Mora" title="Lola Mora">Lola Mora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rogelio_Yrurtia" title="Rogelio Yrurtia">Rogelio Yrurtia</a> authored many of the classical evocative monuments of the Argentine cityscape.
</p><p>The colonization brought the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Baroque_architecture" title="Spanish Baroque architecture">Spanish Baroque architecture</a>, which can still be appreciated in its simpler <i>Rioplatense</i> style in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Reductions" title="Indian Reductions">reduction</a> of <a href="/wiki/San_Ignacio_Min%C3%AD" title="San Ignacio Miní">San Ignacio Miní</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_C%C3%B3rdoba_(Argentina)" title="Cathedral of Córdoba (Argentina)">Cathedral of Córdoba</a>, and the Cabildo of Luján. Italian and French influences increased at the beginning of the 19th century with strong <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eclectic_architecture" title="Eclectic architecture">eclectic</a> overtones that gave the local architecture a unique feeling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[382]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Argentine_cuisine" title="Argentine cuisine">Argentine cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asado_2005.jpg"><img alt="Table with a cut of Argentine beef, wine, sauces and spices" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="592" data-file-width="896" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Asado_2005.jpg/220px-Asado_2005.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Asado_2005.jpg/330px-Asado_2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Asado_2005.jpg/440px-Asado_2005.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Asado_2005.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Argentine_beef" title="Argentine beef">Argentine beef</a> as <i><a href="/wiki/Asado" title="Asado">asado</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>Besides many of the pasta, sausage and dessert dishes common to continental Europe, Argentines enjoy a wide variety of Indigenous and <a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">Criollo</a> creations, including <i><a href="/wiki/Empanada" title="Empanada">empanadas</a></i> (a small stuffed pastry), <i><a href="/wiki/Locro" title="Locro">locro</a></i> (a mixture of corn, beans, meat, bacon, onion, and gourd), <i><a href="/wiki/Humita" title="Humita">humita</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mate_(beverage)" title="Mate (beverage)">mate</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200679,_199,_221_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200679,_199,_221-407">[383]</a></sup>
</p><p>The country has the highest consumption of <a href="/wiki/Red_meat" title="Red meat">red meat</a> in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[384]</a></sup> traditionally prepared as <i><a href="/wiki/Asado" title="Asado">asado</a></i>, the Argentine barbecue. It is made with various types of meats, often including <i><a href="/wiki/Chorizo" title="Chorizo">chorizo</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Sweetbread" title="Sweetbread">sweetbread</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chitterlings" title="Chitterlings">chitterlings</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Blood_sausage" title="Blood sausage">blood sausage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200679_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200679-409">[385]</a></sup>
</p><p>Common desserts include <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Facturas" title="Facturas">facturas</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Viennese_cuisine" title="Viennese cuisine">Viennese-style</a> pastry), <a href="/wiki/Cake" title="Cake">cakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pancake" title="Pancake">pancakes</a> filled with <i><a href="/wiki/Dulce_de_leche" title="Dulce de leche">dulce de leche</a></i> (a sort of milk <a href="/wiki/Caramel" title="Caramel">caramel</a> jam), <i><a href="/wiki/Alfajor" title="Alfajor">alfajores</a></i> (shortbread cookies sandwiched together with chocolate, <i>dulce de leche</i> or a fruit paste), and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Torta_frita" title="Torta frita">tortas fritas</a></i> (fried cakes)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200031McCloskeyBurford200680,_143_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200031McCloskeyBurford200680,_143-410">[386]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Argentine_wine" title="Argentine wine">Argentine wine</a>, one of the world's finest,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[387]</a></sup> is an integral part of the local menu. <a href="/wiki/Malbec" title="Malbec">Malbec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Torront%C3%A9s" title="Torrontés">Torrontés</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabernet_Sauvignon" title="Cabernet Sauvignon">Cabernet Sauvignon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syrah" title="Syrah">Syrah</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chardonnay" title="Chardonnay">Chardonnay</a> are some of the most sought-after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_varieties" title="International varieties">varieties</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford2006230,_252,_261–62,_265_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford2006230,_252,_261–62,_265-412">[388]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Argentina" title="Sport in Argentina">Sport in Argentina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rus-Arg_2017_(16).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="734" decoding="async" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Rus-Arg_2017_%2816%29.jpg/170px-Rus-Arg_2017_%2816%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Rus-Arg_2017_%2816%29.jpg/255px-Rus-Arg_2017_%2816%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Rus-Arg_2017_%2816%29.jpg/340px-Rus-Arg_2017_%2816%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rus-Arg_2017_(16).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lionel_Messi" title="Lionel Messi">Lionel Messi</a>, seven times <a href="/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or" title="Ballon d'Or">Ballon d'Or</a> winner, is the current captain of the <a href="/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team" title="Argentina national football team">Argentina national football team</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Pato" title="Pato">Pato</a></i> is the <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">national sport</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pato1_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-pato1-413">[389]</a></sup> an ancient horseback game locally originated in the early 1600s and predecessor of <a href="/wiki/Horseball" title="Horseball">horseball</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012124–25_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012124–25-414">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pato2_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-pato2-415">[391]</a></sup> The most popular sport is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_Football" title="Association Football">football</a>. Along with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_national_football_team" title="Brazilian national football team">Brazil</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_national_football_team" title="French national football team">France</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team" title="Argentina national football team">men's national team</a> is the only one to have won the most important international triplet: <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">World Cup</a>, <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="FIFA Confederations Cup">Confederations Cup</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Football at the Summer Olympics">Olympic Gold Medal</a>. It has also won 15 <a href="/wiki/Copa_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Copa América">Copas América</a>, 7 <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Pan_American_Games" title="Football at the Pan American Games">Pan American Gold Medals</a> and many other trophies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201214–23_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201214–23-416">[392]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alfredo_Di_St%C3%A9fano" title="Alfredo Di Stéfano">Alfredo Di Stéfano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diego_Maradona" title="Diego Maradona">Diego Maradona</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Messi" title="Lionel Messi">Lionel Messi</a> are among the best players in the game's history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFriedman200756,_127_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFriedman200756,_127-417">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p>The country's <a href="/wiki/Argentina_women%27s_national_field_hockey_team" title="Argentina women's national field hockey team">women's field hockey team <i>Las Leonas</i></a>, is one of the world's most successful with four <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Field hockey at the Summer Olympics">Olympic medals</a>, two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Women%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="Women's Hockey World Cup">World Cups</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIH_Hockey_World_League" title="FIH Hockey World League">World League</a> and seven <a href="/wiki/Hockey_Champions_Trophy" title="Hockey Champions Trophy">Champions Trophy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201211_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201211-418">[394]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Luciana_Aymar" title="Luciana Aymar">Luciana Aymar</a> is recognized as the best female player in the history of the sport,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hwc1_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-hwc1-419">[395]</a></sup> being the only player to have received the <a href="/wiki/FIH_Player_of_the_Year_Awards" title="FIH Player of the Year Awards">FIH Player of the Year Award</a> eight times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fih1_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-fih1-420">[396]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">Basketball</a> is a very popular sport. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentina_national_basketball_team" title="Argentina national basketball team">men's national team</a> is the only one in the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Americas" title="FIBA Americas">FIBA Americas</a> zone that has won the quintuplet crown: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_World_Championship" title="FIBA World Championship">World Championship</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the Summer Olympics">Olympic Gold Medal</a>, <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Diamond_Ball" title="FIBA Diamond Ball">Diamond Ball</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_Americas_Championship" title="FIBA Americas Championship">Americas Championship</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Pan_American_Games" title="Basketball at the Pan American Games">Pan American Gold Medal</a>. It has also conquered 13 <a href="/wiki/South_American_Basketball_Championship" title="South American Basketball Championship">South American Championships</a>, and many other tournaments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fiba1_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-fiba1-421">[397]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emanuel_Gin%C3%B3bili" title="Emanuel Ginóbili">Emanuel Ginóbili</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luis_Scola" title="Luis Scola">Luis Scola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Nocioni" title="Andrés Nocioni">Andrés Nocioni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fabricio_Oberto" title="Fabricio Oberto">Fabricio Oberto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Prigioni" title="Pablo Prigioni">Pablo Prigioni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Delfino" title="Carlos Delfino">Carlos Delfino</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ignacio_S%C3%A1nchez" title="Juan Ignacio Sánchez">Juan Ignacio Sánchez</a> are a few of the country's most acclaimed players, all of them part of the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">NBA</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201211_418-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201211-418">[394]</a></sup> Argentina hosted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basketball_World_Cup" title="Basketball World Cup">Basketball World Cup</a> in 1950 and 1990.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rugby_Union" title="Rugby Union">Rugby</a> is another popular sport in Argentina. As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Argentina_national_rugby_union_team" title="Argentina national rugby union team">men's national team</a>, known as 'Los Pumas' has competed at the <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">Rugby World Cup</a> each time it has been held, achieving their highest ever result in <a href="/wiki/2007_Rugby_World_Cup" title="2007 Rugby World Cup">2007</a> when they came third. Since <a href="/wiki/2012_Rugby_Championship" title="2012 Rugby Championship">2012</a> the Los Pumas have competed against <a href="/wiki/Australia_national_rugby_union_team" title="Australia national rugby union team">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_union_team" title="New Zealand national rugby union team">New Zealand</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/South_Africa_national_rugby_union_team" title="South Africa national rugby union team">South Africa</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Rugby_Championship" title="The Rugby Championship">The Rugby Championship</a>, the premier international Rugby competition in the Southern Hemisphere. Since 2009 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentina_Jaguars" title="Argentina Jaguars">secondary men's national team</a> known as the 'Jaguares' has competed against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USA_Selects" title="USA Selects">US</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada_A_national_rugby_union_team" title="Canada A national rugby union team">Canada</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_rugby_union_team" title="Uruguay national rugby union team">Uruguay</a> first teams in the <a href="/wiki/Americas_Rugby_Championship" title="Americas Rugby Championship">Americas Rugby Championship</a>, which Los Jaguares have won six out of eight times it has taken place.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="949" data-file-width="733" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg/170px-Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg/255px-Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg/340px-Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Campeonato_Argentino_de_Polo_2010_-_5236515585_2b8cb412de_o.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Campeonato_Argentino_Abierto_de_Polo" title="Campeonato Argentino Abierto de Polo">Argentine Polo Open Championship</a></div></div></div>
<p>Argentina has produced some of the most formidable champions for <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">Boxing</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Monz%C3%B3n" title="Carlos Monzón">Carlos Monzón</a>, the best <a href="/wiki/Middleweight" title="Middleweight">middleweight</a> in history;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thering1_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-thering1-422">[398]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pascual_P%C3%A9rez_(boxer)" title="Pascual Pérez (boxer)">Pascual Pérez</a>, one of the most decorated <a href="/wiki/Flyweight" title="Flyweight">flyweight</a> boxers of all times; <a href="/wiki/Horacio_Accavallo" title="Horacio Accavallo">Horacio Accavallo</a>, the former <a href="/wiki/World_Boxing_Association" title="World Boxing Association">WBA</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_Boxing_Council" title="World Boxing Council">WBC</a> world flyweight champion; <a href="/wiki/V%C3%ADctor_Gal%C3%ADndez" title="Víctor Galíndez">Víctor Galíndez</a>, as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> record holder for consecutive world <a href="/wiki/Light_heavyweight" title="Light heavyweight">light heavyweight</a> title defenses and <a href="/wiki/Nicolino_Locche" title="Nicolino Locche">Nicolino Locche</a>, nicknamed "The Untouchable" for his masterful defense; they are all inductees into the <a href="/wiki/International_Boxing_Hall_of_Fame" title="International Boxing Hall of Fame">International Boxing Hall of Fame</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERodríguez2009164–65_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERodríguez2009164–65-423">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">Tennis</a> has been quite popular among people of all ages. <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Vilas" title="Guillermo Vilas">Guillermo Vilas</a> is the greatest Latin American player of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_tennis" title="History of tennis">Open Era</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012144_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012144-424">[400]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Gabriela_Sabatini" title="Gabriela Sabatini">Gabriela Sabatini</a> is the most accomplished Argentine female player of all time—having reached number 3 in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WTA_ranking" title="WTA ranking">WTA ranking</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012135_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012135-425">[401]</a></sup> are both inductees into the <a href="/wiki/International_Tennis_Hall_of_Fame" title="International Tennis Hall of Fame">International Tennis Hall of Fame</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ithf1_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-ithf1-426">[402]</a></sup> Argentina has won the <a href="/wiki/World_Team_Cup" title="World Team Cup">World Team Cup</a> four times, in 1980, 2002, <a href="/wiki/2007_ARAG_World_Team_Cup" title="2007 ARAG World Team Cup">2007</a> and <a href="/wiki/2010_ARAG_World_Team_Cup" title="2010 ARAG World Team Cup">2010</a> and has reached the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/Davis_Cup" title="Davis Cup">Davis Cup</a> 7 times in the last 10 years, losing the finals against Russia in <a href="/wiki/2006_Davis_Cup" title="2006 Davis Cup">2006</a> and Spain in <a href="/wiki/2008_Davis_Cup" title="2008 Davis Cup">2008</a> and <a href="/wiki/2011_Davis_Cup" title="2011 Davis Cup">2011</a>; the Argentine team also played the final in <a href="/wiki/1981_Davis_Cup" title="1981 Davis Cup">1981</a>, where they lost against the United States. The national squad won the <a href="/wiki/2016_Davis_Cup" title="2016 Davis Cup">2016 Davis Cup</a>.
</p><p>Argentina reigns undisputed in <a href="/wiki/Polo" title="Polo">Polo</a>, having won more international championships than any other country and been seldom beaten since the 1930s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200050–51_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200050–51-427">[403]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Campeonato_Argentino_Abierto_de_Polo" title="Campeonato Argentino Abierto de Polo">Argentine Polo Championship</a> is the sport's most important international team trophy. The country is home to most of the world's top players, among them <a href="/wiki/Adolfo_Cambiaso" title="Adolfo Cambiaso">Adolfo Cambiaso</a>, the best in Polo history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012128_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish2012128-428">[404]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, Argentina has had a strong showing within <a href="/wiki/Auto_racing" title="Auto racing">Auto racing</a>. <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Fangio" title="Juan Manuel Fangio">Juan Manuel Fangio</a> was five times <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> world champion under four different teams, winning 102 of his 184 international races, and is widely ranked as the greatest driver of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201298Dougall2013170–171_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaurightParrish201298Dougall2013170–171-429">[405]</a></sup> Other distinguished racers were <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Alfredo_G%C3%A1lvez" title="Oscar Alfredo Gálvez">Oscar Alfredo Gálvez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juan_G%C3%A1lvez_(racing_driver)" title="Juan Gálvez (racing driver)">Juan Gálvez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Froil%C3%A1n_Gonz%C3%A1lez" title="José Froilán González">José Froilán González</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Reutemann" title="Carlos Reutemann">Carlos Reutemann</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbena1999147Dougall2013170–171,_195_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbena1999147Dougall2013170–171,_195-430">[406]</a></sup>
</p>
